review_preview: My husband and I were browsing restaurants for dinner on Yelp, and El Sur had favourable reviews and was not too far from our apartment so we decided to check it out. Upon entering, we were warmly greeted by Alex and shown to a cozy...
review_full: My husband and I were browsing restaurants for dinner on Yelp, and El Sur had favourable reviews and was not too far from our apartment so we decided to check it out. Upon entering, we were warmly greeted by Alex and shown to a cozy corner table. He asked us how we were doing, where we were from, and was very friendly and welcoming. He suggested we try the sangria as it was a house specialty. We agreed and we're glad we did as it was delicious. For our meal we decided to try some different tapas from the menu. We asked Alex about sizes and quantity and he suggested starting with a few different half portions so that we could try several different dishes. We ordered the Salmorejo soup (served cold), the endive/goat cheese/walnut salad, the curry chicken (served with rice) and the shredded steak (ropa de viejo) served with thinly sliced potatoes. Every dish was delicious and after each bite we were saying "mmmmm"! This is no lie. We were in Spain for 2 weeks, and this was by far our favourite meal and restaurant in Madrid. After we finished our dinner, Alex asked us if we'd like any dessert. He showed us the options and had us sold on the passionfruit cheesecake. OMG, it was sooooo good!! Everything we ate was superb and the service was top notch. If you are in Madrid and want an easy, laid back atmosphere with great food, and very friendly staff, not to mention very reasonably priced (our whole meal including 2 very large glasses of sangria, 4 tapas dishes, bread basket, and dessert) was only $29 euros in total), then El Sur should be #1 on your list. They also have a prix fix lunch menu for 9 euros which includes appetizer, entree, drink, dessert and bread basket. Just fantastic!!

title_review: Delicious food, and the nicest staff I've encountered on my trip!
review_preview: I stopped in here thanks to a recommendation of a friend who used to live in Madrid, and I'm so glad I did! I ordered the menu del dia which came with a huge starter of the most delicious mushroom and chicken risotto, which I...
review_full: I stopped in here thanks to a recommendation of a friend who used to live in Madrid, and I'm so glad I did! I ordered the menu del dia which came with a huge starter of the most delicious mushroom and chicken risotto, which I followed with a main dish of fresh Salmon in Yogurt sauce and salad. It was soooo good! Next was dessert. In my other experiences, the postre that comes with the menu is small and plain (vanilla ice cream/ chocolate pudding).... well not at this place. You had a choice between a generous slice of chocolate, carrot, or red velvet cakes or two different types of cheese cake. Did I mention that this was all for about 10 euro? Not only was the food to die for, but the staff was super friendly. I was having a hard day due to some personal circumstances but the guys working were so personable and and kept stopping by to chat, especially Alex. I ended up leaving with a big smile on my face and will definitely be back. I can't recommend this place enough!

I've tried the tortelonni alla zucca (pasta filled with pumpkin and truffle) and it has exceeded any expectations!  They also have a very nice bar, but unfortunately it was too early for me to try their cocktail.  Overall, the restaurant is definitely a safe option with unique food in the heart of one of the best areas in Madrid.

title_review: You Know Its Real Good When You Return in the Same Week
review_preview: Ate at this place on our first night in Madrid.  We had 5 nights in Madrid before heading to London.  We ate at this place on our first and last nights while in Madrid.  I had done my homework before departing the states to Madrid....
review_full: Ate at this place on our first night in Madrid. We had 5 nights in Madrid before heading to London. We ate at this place on our first and last nights while in Madrid. I had done my homework before departing the states to Madrid. The restaurant was on our radar. So glad we ate here. The steak was tender, juicy, and very flavorful. The basket of bread was an awesome treat of different types of bread - fresh and tasty. Very good selection of wines, and especially in the moderate range. Most importantly, the staff were all professional, accommodating, and attentive without crowding. The Restaurants provides a complimentary glass of bubbly and a bisque when seated. They also provide a couple of mini-deserts including sorbet. It's those little pieces of recognition that give this restaurant the extra bonus over other restaurants. The second night we had the steak again and added the grilled chicken. That chicken was amazing! No one can accuse this restaurant of using inferior chickens or meat. The flavors told of its freshness. I don't recall the sauce that came with the chicken, but it wasn't heavy or overbearing. Strongly recommend this restaurant... me and others can't be that wrong ~

title_review: My Favorite Tapas place in Madrid!

In addition to traditional tapas of fried calamari, cuttlefish or sardines ..Casa Toni is the place for adventurous eaters! From pig ears to neck glands from lamb, to fries pig intestines! If I ever make it back to Madrid Casa Toni would be my first choice for food!

review_preview: Innovative, creative, inventive, playful, surprising. Excellent quality of food. Great staff. I'm a foodie and a tough restaurant critic, and this was one of the best meals I've ever eaten -- and, by far, the most inventive. A great value!! The marinade mackerel with cabbage...

review_preview: ... so if glitzy, gimmicky presentation doesn't do anything for you, don't eat here! I loved it. This isn't a meal, it's food as theatre. So imaginative, every tiny dish leaves you a) wondering how they did it and b) wishing there was just a...
review_full: ... so if glitzy, gimmicky presentation doesn't do anything for you, don't eat here! I loved it. This isn't a meal, it's food as theatre. So imaginative, every tiny dish leaves you a) wondering how they did it and b) wishing there was just a tiny bit more. La pezera, a little fishbowl of a dessert, was so good I nearly wept, while there were other courses that made us spontaneously smile. Everyone talks about the mini Babybel and the poached egg, but I think this is just because they are easy to describe -- there were other dishes I liked better. At the end of the meal we were each given a little scroll listing what we'd eaten, with the wine pairings -- a nice touch, as I'd been taking photos of every dish in order to keep track. For me it's probably a once in a lifetime experience. I have only paid this much for a meal (about 300 euros for two) on two other occasions -- Lapeyrouse in Paris and Michel Bras at Laguiole. Both meals were superb, but left me feeling guilty about spending so much money on a single meal. This experience surpassed both of those. You may not remember every detail, but the experience as a whole is unforgettable.

title_review: Not as good as the reviews make it sound
review_preview: We went to the restaurant as part of a tapas tour.  Apparently, it is a local favorite.  In my opinion it was the least interesting food of the tour.  The restaurant is packed with locals, tourists and tapas tours.  We tried the calamari, boiled ham,...
review_full: We went to the restaurant as part of a tapas tour. Apparently, it is a local favorite. In my opinion it was the least interesting food of the tour.  The restaurant is packed with locals, tourists and tapas tours. We tried the calamari, boiled ham, sweetbread, tomato salad and chorizo. They were all ok but certainly didn't leave a lasting impression. The best thing we had were the fried green chili peppers. Apparently, it is possible to stumble upon a really hot one, but all of the chilis on our plate were mild and delicious. I wouldn't go out of my way to dine at the restaurant but if you find yourself in the neighborhood it's fine for dinner.

review_preview: Had our last dinner at this very small, unassuming tapas bar. Both ordered a drink to start and received a complimentary fried black pudding on bread. We then ordered some tapas which was cooked right in front of us. We were going to order more...
review_full: Had our last dinner at this very small, unassuming tapas bar. Both ordered a drink to start and received a complimentary fried black pudding on bread. We then ordered some tapas which was cooked right in front of us. We were going to order more but he stopped us short and said there was enough. We got the patatas bravas, mushrooms and fried eggplant. We both agreed that they were the best potatoes, best mushrooms and best eggplant we'd ever had. To top it off, we then got a complimentary sherry once we'd finished. The meal came to a total of about 20 euros each including a drink each. When in Madrid, this is a must.

review_preview: I must say I have mixed feelings about El Club Allard. My wife enjoyed it thoroughly, and I did mostly, but presentation is much more memorable than actual cuisine here, and the pretense is sometimes simply a bit much. The first course was mackerel marinated...
review_full: I must say I have mixed feelings about El Club Allard. My wife enjoyed it thoroughly, and I did mostly, but presentation is much more memorable than actual cuisine here, and the pretense is sometimes simply a bit much. The first course was mackerel marinated in tiger milk, more impressive in labeling than in taste (can anyone actually discern the difference between tiger milk vs. any other milk as marinade?). The last course was served in a smoking (dry ice) dish with a sugar Buddha on top, and I simply cannot recall what the actual dish was. In fact, few of the many courses were memorable. Taken as a whole, it's an interesting experience, but I frankly preferred the actual cuisine of a few other restaurants on this trip.

review_preview: I love this kind of places, it doesn't even look like a restaurant but some kind of an old and chic building with a huge first floor flat transformed into a restaurant.Very simple decoration, all white and grey, with nice music in the background....
review_full: I love this kind of places, it doesn't even look like a restaurant but some kind of an old and chic building with a huge first floor flat transformed into a restaurant. Very simple decoration, all white and grey, with nice music in the background. On the food front, it is a typical modern fusion place - you just choose between three menus (differentiated by number of dishes going from 8 --2 pre starters, 2 starters, a fish, a meat and few desserts-- to 15) and after usual inquiry about allergies here goes a festival of small tasting portions It was both delicious and interesting (ok, sometimes more interesting that delicious but in any case worth trying). The menu changes every season, so by the time you are here it might be different but I had: - mayonnaise mousse to be eaten with what looks like a paper card but turns out to be made out of potato (more interesting than delicious) - small bread with garlic butter - foie gras with truffle game mousse and eucalyptus wind ! - amazing camembert babybel with truffles - caviar, turnip flake, cauliflower cream  - mizo soup with white fish sashimi, very tasty and good After those pre starters, actual starters were: - delicious vegetable soup served in plastic bag ! - a never changing dish, an egg in thin slice of toasted bread served with some pancetta - smoked salmon throat (sic !) with coconut air (re-sic !!!) followed by two mains: - halibut belly with citrus air (!) (and actually the 'air' is really tasty) - lamb with pistachio (amazing & melting !) and then by few desserts: - strawberry gin and tonic - fish bowl (too drunk by now to describe the content but there was a lot of eucalyptus air, red white chocolate, dark chocolate mussel, etc) - slight overkill... - surprise egg (ok, it really looks like an egg) - buddha face with mint air... - you need to discover that ! do not touch otherwise delicious bread as you will run out of steam by second starter ! Almost 40 pages long wine list is great and well priced; being alone i got sommelier to choose --too many-- glasses of wine, mainly spanish, all being great matches with various dishes. All in, an amazing place - I still love tapas but from time to time it is worth trying something very different and original; only drawback, if i had to add one, is that between the decoration and design of dishes, everything is a bit Star Trek style, but still delicious and worth trying for roughly 140 eur.

Although the waiter didn't really speak English he was very friendly and helpful. He gave me samples of the white wine because I couldn't read the menu to pick. And to finish the meal there was a complementary sherry.

title_review: Where's The Italian in the Food ?   Mediocre at Best....
review_preview: I was excited about experiencing this restaurant because of the reviews of "excellence."  Not sure what the criteria is for "excellence", but this restaurant was mediocre at best.  The pasta was undercooked, not even al dente.  I had the Salmon Vodka, which was flavorless -...
review_full: I was excited about experiencing this restaurant because of the reviews of "excellence." Not sure what the criteria is for "excellence", but this restaurant was mediocre at best. The pasta was undercooked, not even al dente. I had the Salmon Vodka, which was flavorless - quite bland. Our waiter Mauro appeared lost in mind, and also appeared lost for quite some time -- he was nonexistent. I noted that most diners ordered pizzas. So, perhaps that's why this place gets some good reviews. But, I never considered a pizza place an "Italian Restaurant." Also, the place appears to be pretty pretentious. Good food doesn't have to be pretentious .... good food stands on its own. I wouldn't return here -- too expensive for bland food. I don't mind paying $$$$ for good food, but it better be good, and not just window dressing.

title_review: Better Than Other Top Restaurants in Madrid
review_preview: Club Allard was just one of four Michelin Star restaurants my partner and I were visiting in as many days during this visit to Madrid.(If you are interested the others were Terraza del Casino for the second time, Diverxo for the fourth time and...
review_full: Club Allard was just one of four Michelin Star restaurants my partner and I were visiting in as many days during this visit to Madrid. (If you are interested the others were Terraza del Casino for the second time, Diverxo for the fourth time and Punto MX for the first time). It was our second visit to Club Allard, but our first visit with the current chef. Of the four restaurants that we visited this was the one that blew me away the most. We had the longest tasting menu available and did wine pairing too. Our first impression, after the elegant and neat decor, was the professionalism of our sommelier and spectacular knowledge of our waiter. We had told the sommelier that we don't like run-of-the-mill wines and that we don't want to taste anything that we can drink at home in Mallorca. He embraced the project and took on the challenge, taking us through a wonderful journey of little-known wines all with a great story. Not that we loved them all, but the sommelier really appreciated our comments and occasionally brought us two wines so we could give our opinion of what went best with the dish. He really pulled out the stops.  The sommelier also gave me a list of the wines we had so if you want to know more, please ask. Our waiter too, was a credit to the restaurant. When we go to restaurants for fine dining, especially with modern cuisine, we like to ask about the preparation and elaboration of dishes. Our waiter was able to answer everything unfazed and also give us information about ingredients, for example something that came from a small village in the north of Cuba... The tasting menu was classic in its presentation and modern in the style of cuisine. The dishes were clearly thought out and the whole thing was consistent and well balanced.  My favourite dish was the "cup cake de huevo y trufa". When you go, please do ask for this dish to be included, it was very surprising and was excellent. At the end of the meal we met Maria Marte, the now head chef, and she was an absolute delight to talk to. She oozed passion and she had her ideas very clear. When asked which dish of the menu represents most her style of cuisine and why, she was able to answer without hesitation. Her answer (which I have posted on my blog: InMyShoesTravel) absolutely blew me away. She 100% deserves her two Michelin stars, having started out at this restaurant as a pot washer. I also have a copy of the menu which we had. If you have any questions, please ask.

title_review: Only 1 out of 3 courses were great!
review_preview: My Husband and I had the largest of the 3 tasting menus for lunch. The lunch started well, with good service and the fact that you can eat your menu! The wine list was also good and reasonably priced. However, we were disappointed with the...
review_full: My Husband and I had the largest of the 3 tasting menus for lunch. The lunch started well, with good service and the fact that you can eat your menu! The wine list was also good and reasonably priced. However, we were disappointed with the food overall.  We have been lucky to visit many 2 and 3 Michelin starred restaurants all over the world and overall we were surprised that this restaurant has any Michelin stars as it falls very short of its peers: Every 1 out of 3 courses was excellent. However the remaining courses all tasted pretty much the same - overly fishy and salty. There were far too many fishy salty soups and broths for our liking.  The deer course was great and the desserts were good, but that's about it. We were very disappointed that my Husband was served a cheese dish for one of the main courses, despite explaining that he had an allergy to cheese. Instead of making him a different main course, they instead skipped a main dish. Given that we were paying for the largest tasting menu, it was a disgrace that they didn't bring him another dish. Also one of our dishes was absolutely inedible - a fishy bean dish - which we couldn't eat, and they didn't even bother to change it for something else! (We did notice however that they did offer a Spanish table a change of dish when they couldn't eat one of their fishy salty dishes!). So overall, we would not be going back and left somewhat disappointed. We left the lunch hungry, almost 400 euros lighter and ended up eating a full 3 course dinner 4 hours later at El Paraguas!!!

review_preview: I never thought that we would get into this highly rated Madrid restaurant but the concierge at our hotel performed magic and voila, we had a reservation. Then I started to read some of the reviews posted by people who live in my same geographical...
review_full: I never thought that we would get into this highly rated Madrid restaurant but the concierge at our hotel performed magic and voila, we had a reservation. Then I started to read some of the reviews posted by people who live in my same geographical area and I got nervous that we were going to spend a lot of money and have an awful time. Well, having dined at El Club Allard, I urge everyone to ignore those naysayers and embark on the best culinary experience of your life. Yes, you eat the menu as the first course, but it goes up and up from there. The service is impeccable, our server longed for us to enjoy the food. It was quite amusing watching him try to encourage some other diners who were obviously not foodies push the food around their plates. Why go to a restaurant like this for a true dining experience if you don't appreciate the cuisine. The only way to describe some of the dishes is "trompe l'oiel", which is to say that it looks like one thing and tastes like another. The presentation is gorgeous and so clever and the tastes are out of this world. My favorite was the "onion soup: which was presented as ice cream with caramel sauce but was in fact the most delicious onion soup with cheese.The sommelier was top notch and so personable. The chef de cusine presented herself at the end of the serving and I managed to get a tour of the kitchen which was gorgeous. My advice is that you get out of it what you put in, if you go in with the right attitude, you will absolutely love everything. Others apparently are prepped to criticize so nothing will seem right. We loved it and this is a meal that I will remember and savour for a lifetime.

review_preview: Given the praise this restaurant has received and is continuing to receive, I had a hard time to come up with what I wanted to say in this review. The food definitely deserves more than the 3 point rating I am giving overall, but for...
review_full: Given the praise this restaurant has received and is continuing to receive, I had a hard time to come up with what I wanted to say in this review. The food definitely deserves more than the 3 point rating I am giving overall, but for the experience I had and considering I have been too forgiving in the overall ratings before, I have to be more rigorous on this one. It was the classical "restaurant with great food and reputation, but you somehow felt awkwardly misplaced" kind of journey. Now I do not know if our table's main waiter had a bad day or if the fact that we might have been generally younger than the usual guests was what made it so extremely awkward, but one should leave a restaurant feeling happy due to other reasons than being able to flee the uneasiness - starting from the welcoming part to when you finally set foot outside of it again. But let's talk about the food. Starting with choosing the menu and having to eat the little sheet of "paper" right after was a great and funny twist to the experience, yet it did lack of taste. The edible paper (so to say) was not much more than what you were used to as a kid. Fun but tasteless and the kind of mayonnaise served with it didn't help.  That being said it goes uphill from now on. The grilled sea selection with essential oils that followed later during the menu was a delicious composition. Amazing presentation, well thought through and the interactive part with the oil just gave it the extra kick to make this dish one to remember.  There isn't much to say about every single dish, given I had struggled with this review and it is some time ago now too. Yet on the other hand the food was an average good to very good and so what I will still be mentioning are simply the highlights that cannot be left unsaid.  Hence the cold cherry soup with herring caviar. What a dream! I have yet to try this myself. Imagine yourself on a hot and dry day in Spain, sitting outside a finca, resting in the shadow of a big old tree and refreshing yourself with cold and cherry-flavored spoons full of tranquility. It was a pairing of tastes I have not yet had the chance to enjoy before, an idea that is quite simple actually, but so splendid and surprising that it is yet another one of those dishes at el club Allard that will stick to one's mind.  As of the desserts, they were outstanding by themselves. In particular the hibiscus flower with Pisco Sour. This little creation has simply been a masterpiece! Taking on the much earlier eaten freshness of the cherry soup (as if as an homage) and yet still keeping the sweetness needed in a dessert. Crunchy, sour, fizzy, creamy - combining it all to a very exquisite piece of art. Talking about an exquisite piece of art one cannot leave out the fishbowl. Now that is a memory. It is amazing to see what can be done with sugar and sweets and chocolate. This is, on the creative side, a bravo to the cuisine! Although as of taste it could not quite hold up with the hibiscus flower.  To not go on and on about every detail of each dessert or dish in general, this restaurant does not lack of creativity in its food. Not in the flavors, not the presentation, not the way you might sometimes have to eat it. It is a modern and delightful experience in that concern. The ambience as well is rather modern and promising. Yet what it definitely lacks and causes me to be harsh in my overall rating is the heart. The warmth. The Spanish sun that when coming inside makes you want to stay and come again. I will be happy to return but remain sincerely hopeful to experience a more cheerful staff and leave with a smile, rather than a sigh of relief.

All of which were superb, we washed it down with lots of the delicious fruity sangria, service was fine it's a very busy place and don't be out of if it looks full there is more seating upstairs. We got free shots of some kind of Apple liquor when we left. 2 glasses of sangria and 6 dishes between us came to £44 euros! Brilliant value !

review_preview: Their menu offers a huge variety - from the usual fare that you will find in tapas bars to the very unusual, such as: lamb intestines, grilled kidneys, sweetbreads.  We stopped in for lunch and it was great!  My wife had grilled mini-peppers and chorizo...

We stopped in for lunch and it was great! My wife had grilled mini-peppers and chorizo boiled in wine - she says that both were delicious. I started with a gazpacho, which was excellent! This was followed by a large serving of grilled chopped pig's ears - something I've never experienced before. It was quite good - very tender and quite filling. Their prices are quite reasonable. If we would have had one more day in Madrid, I'm sure we would have returned to try some more of their very interesting offerings.

review_preview: What you get at Club Allard is an evening of pure delight. We went for broke with the Revolucion menu and wine paring and did not regret a euro of it. The wait staff were very attentive and courteous throughout the evening and did a...
review_full: What you get at Club Allard is an evening of pure delight. We went for broke with the Revolucion menu and wine paring and did not regret a euro of it. The wait staff were very attentive and courteous throughout the evening and did a good job in describing each of the 14 dishes on the menu. And, we were given a copy of the menu at the end as a keepsake.  Each dish was beautifully presented, with visual and scent enhancements which added to the pleasure of the dish. We were amazed at the inventiveness of the dishes and there was not one item on the menu which was not delicious. The wine pairings nicely complimented all of the dishes also. The price was exceptional considering the quality of the cuisine.  This is not a restaurant to go and get a big steak dinner, though I'm sure if they had it on the menu it would be outstanding, but one where you can go to enjoy local ingredients expertly cooked to become tasty gems.  And thank you Chef Diego for sending me home with my own "egg" - a truly delightful end to our evening.

title_review: If I only had one meal in Madrid, this should be it!
review_preview: Although it was a challenge to make a reservation since the person I spoke to didn't speak English and I don't speak any Spanish, we managed to make a reservation for lunch. I had read some pretty good reviews of the restaurant but the lunch...

I had read some pretty good reviews of the restaurant but the lunch still exceeded my expectations. The food was creative and tasty and the atmosphere was relaxed.  Most of the waiters spoke perfect English, but the best part was actually that the ones who didn't, still made a great effort to tackle it with a smile, which only made us have a laugh together and made us feel welcome.  After the menu the head chef came out to greet us and asked if everything had been ok (he seemed to do that at every table), which in my opinion is a very nice gesture. All in all I can highly recommend a visit to this restaurant. I know where I'll be sure to make reservations, next time I'm in Madrid!!

title_review: Finally found the red wine that matches fish!
review_preview: Just back to Madrid to celebrate Christmas, we booked the place three months ago online. And the experience was definitely gorgeous and fabulous.The restaurant is in a representative building in the center of Madrid. The decoration is neoclassical but modest.You can choose between...
review_full: Just back to Madrid to celebrate Christmas, we booked the place three months ago online. And the experience was definitely gorgeous and fabulous. The restaurant is in a representative building in the center of Madrid. The decoration is neoclassical but modest. You can choose between 11,13 or 15 courses with price between 86, 98 or 115€. Way far cheap for the standard of an 2 Michelin star restaurant! Especially comparing with Italy or France. I wonder if it's because of the Spanish committee is too picky and demanding?! Anyway, we chose the 13 course menu and ordered the sommelier to match the wine for us (47€ per head). We were very much satisfied and feeling just right after the lunch. The lunch starts with a surprise, the menu card can be eaten with the aperitif. We after the waiter to not explain us the plate but just when we finished and guessed the ingredients and the way of preparation. Hey, after all I was 70% right. It was lots of fun even for the waiters! If you have a sensible taste, please do so! We loved all the courses, the potential ones were "chupito de pez mantequilla y espárrago blanco", "sardina ahumada con crema de apio-nabo y manzana", "arroz del mar", and "rodaballo al horno con ahumado de arbequin".  I need to mention the sommelier and send him congratulations. I told him that I love red wine and he changed the white wine to a lighter A.O.C Bourgogne (Confuron-Cotetidot Pinot Noir 2011) to match the monk fish. It emphasized the fish texture and the smokey taste and in the meantime the wine being smooth and potential. It was a wonderful match and the after flavor was chocolate with cherry in your mouth.  Probably the dessert is not the strength of the chef that I would say. There was one plate that I felt it didn't make sense. When we finished the lunch, they gave us the list of the wine and the courses that we ate. It was a very nice detail, and I was trying to eat them again, lol. We very much enjoyed the meal! Well done!

title_review: My Second and Perhaps Final Visit to el Club Allard
review_preview: El Club Allard is a fine restaurant, but the problem is that you must eat whatever the chef selects for you, which is not necessarily what you would prefer. Dinner starts with a so-called “menu” that is in fact a price list where you can...
review_full: El Club Allard is a fine restaurant, but the problem is that you must eat whatever the chef selects for you, which is not necessarily what you would prefer. Dinner starts with a so-called “menu” that is in fact a price list where you can only choose one of three menus, the difference being how many items you will be served and the price, the more items to be served the costlier your meal will be, of course. Choices are, I believe, 89€ for 11 items or “steps”, as they call them, 98€ for 13 “steps”, or 128€ for 15 “steps”. And that's all you can choose.  When I asked my waiter what the “steps” consisted of, or what options were available within the “steps” to be served, he declined to tell me, saying only that would be the chef's “surprise”. The so-called “menu” is edible, and tasteless, but it is accompanied by a very tasty sauce in which the waiter invites you to dip the “menu”, which makes it a very good amuse bouche. Many “steps” that I was served were excellent, but some I did not like. The failure to allow one to choose what one would prefer to be served can of course lead to the chef sending the wrong “surprise” to your table. For example, at a neighboring table a lady who did not eat chicken at all was served a chicken “step”, while at the same time I was served an equivalent pigeon “step”. If we had been able to choose I would have indicated that I preferred the chicken that was served to the lady who did not eat chicken; and certainly the lady in the neighboring table would have said that she did not eat chicken before the chicken was served to her.  In general the “steps” I was served leaned towards seafood too much for my taste; I would have preferred more meat and less seafood, but I was never asked or even allowed to tell because the chef wanted to “surprise” me. The prior time that I visited el Club Allard the final “step” of the meal one could swear was a hard boiled egg, but in fact it was a frozen dessert. That dessert was one of the highlights of the meal and I understood it to be a trademark of this restaurant. Well, no egg this time, and I really missed it. Service was good but not outstanding. Spanish is my native language, but often I was not able to understand what my waiter was saying because instead of speaking clearly he spoke too fast and mumbling. And instead of placing cutlery on the table, the waiter always seemed to drop it, sometimes from a distance; weird I think. Otherwise service was fine. My first dinner at el Club Allard was one year before my most recent visit in December 2014. My recollection is that my original dinner at el Club Allard was far more enjoyable, a truly memorable experience; maybe the chef guessed better what I preferred to eat, or perhaps it was another chef. Be that as it may, I now feel that I will not return to el Club Allard because this time my meal was not spectacular, as I recall was my prior meal at this restaurant. And anyway instead of having the chef “surprise” me, I prefer to have a say in what I want to eat.

title_review: A warning for those of you who appreciate good food and good service
review_preview: I want to qualify this review by telling the reader that this is one of the six restaurants that we ate in during the last week of November 2014. To put this review in context, we were six people who were in Madrid four days...
review_full: I want to qualify this review by telling the reader that this is one of the six restaurants that we ate in during the last week of November 2014. To put this review in context, we were six people who were in Madrid four days re-visiting and trying new restaurants. We ate at Casa Lucio, (twice lunch and a late dinner), El Paraguas, La Trainera and O'Pazo which were all stellar. We also ate at Ten Con Ten which was okay but highly overrated.  I have never written a bad review as I would not want to hurt the people who make their living by working in a service industry. Having said that, I can not hold back my absolute contempt for the food, the service and the ambience of El Club Allard. This was on my list of fine restaurants in Madrid; it should never have been on my list or any other list when it comes to gourmet dining. The gimmicks of eating a tasteless paper, akin to receiving a communion wafer, was just the start. The cold razor clams were dirty with grit. The silly foam additions on every other plate were totally lacking of flavor, truly a new low in Spanish cuisine. The turbot was like rubber. We had the Superior menu which only meant we had more insipid dishes than any one person should ever try to eat.  What was truly appalling was the service! We had a waiter who thought it was funny to plop down our silverware after each course. He seemed to have some personal, internal joke going on that made him speak about each dish as rapidly and incomprehensible as he could. He was rude and insulting. I had wanted to walk out after the first ten minutes but did not want to embarrass the rest of the members in my party. This was a mistake because two of our guests were sick with food poisoning for 24 hours, ruining two days of our holiday. To finish up, the ambience of the room that we sat in was cold and dark; a gray room made especially for visiting tourists. I apologize to the reviewers who had a good meal here but I truly recommend you try the restaurants that I mentioned in the beginning of this review, so as to know where the great food, excellent service and warm ambience can be enjoyed while in Madrid.

Upon entering this opulent venue we were greeted with excellent service and taken to our table. The setting is extremely formal which is to be expected for such an opulent restaurant and the menu we were given was a three options of which we chose to eat the most expensive as it was a special treat for us all. Being the food lover we enjoyed every single plate that was offered to us on the menu, each plate was explained by our waiter and each plate was a work of art created by the chefs from the kitchen. Every plate surpassed the previous one and the menu simply was superb. The experience was excellent and my only criticism was the way to his Cervato table came across the times is rather cold and self-centred however this did not spoil this experience and would recommend this to anybody who is celebrating something special whilst in Madrid. Being given the chance at the end of the experience to see the kitchen in practice was a highlight and meeting the head chef who explained how many people worked in a kitchen and how each plate took time and effort to prepare for the customers it really was special thank U for offering this to us simply first-class.

Our guide ordered quite a few dishes, some good, some excellent, some that weren't my favorite, but food is very subjective. The chorizo was very good, I nibbled the black sausage and the taste was good, the little pickled fish were not to my liking, and I was too squeamish to try the sweetbreads. But the pork chunks, the tomatoes served simply with a little oil, oregano and salt, and the fried eggplant slices were absolutely divine!

review_preview: We had a lovely tenth anniversary dinner last month at Atico at the Principal Hotel.A brief hiccup on arrival - we wanted to go for a drink at the open air rooftop bar, but were told it was full to capacity; on taking the...
review_full: We had a lovely tenth anniversary dinner last month at Atico at the Principal Hotel. A brief hiccup on arrival - we wanted to go for a drink at the open air rooftop bar, but were told it was full to capacity; on taking the lift up there anyway, there was plenty of space! But we left quickly as it didn't offer the views we'd hoped for.  After that, it was amazing! Descending one floor to the restaurant, we found that it was possible to sit outside on their cosy, secluded terrace area - a bonus as we'd hoped to do this but hadn't thought it possible. It offered an interesting perspective of the immediate vicinity below (though isn’t really high enough to provide a wide ranging view of a wider area of the city).  We opted for the €70 seven-course tasting menu (without wine flight). The head waitress and all the staff were excellent at explaining to us (in faultless English) not only what we were about to eat, but on occasions how to eat it...! The standard was very high across all the courses, and service was attentive without overly disturbing us, despite being outside and away from the restaurant's main footfall area. I would recommend Atico restaurant if you're looking for a high-end 'occasion' meal in Madrid.

We decided not to go for the pairing wines, but instead ordered a bottle of rosé, the waiter was extremely helpful with the wine list as we were unsure which rosé to go for. The wine was perfect and it only cost €22 for a bottle! I really enjoyed the puffed bread that came with the first course, it was so tasty and unusual! The suckling pig was also extremely tasty and tender. I would highly recommend this restaurant especially if you are staying at The Principal because you get a 15% discount off the total bill.

title_review: That chicken, that dinner, that breakfast!!
review_preview: It could also be said of the lamb and the pork. Chicken is very difficult to make perfectly and this was perfect!  Atico is tucked away a few feet from the intersection of the V formed where Calle Alcalá and Gran Via meet at Calle...
review_full: It could also be said of the lamb and the pork. Chicken is very difficult to make perfectly and this was perfect!  Atico is tucked away a few feet from the intersection of the V formed where Calle Alcalá and Gran Via meet at Calle Marqués de Valdeiglesias, 1, 28013 Madrid. Tucked away on the six floor of The Principal Hotel behind a modest door and up a small elevator, it’s easy to miss.  The locals find it and so should you! Gourmet dishes. Small, but excellent wine list with at least three selections from each of the major wine regions in Spain at very affordable prices.  They serve gourmet dishes by Michelin starred chef Ramon Freixa at reasonable prices with great service. After dinner you can enjoy a drink on the beautiful terrace or in the hotel lobby.  Reserve early or the locals will take all the tables. Ático is open for lunch and dinner, which starts at 8:30 PM.  Buen provecho.

title_review: A memory of Madrid that ticks all the boxes
review_preview: What can we say but wow!  A fantastic afternoon spent with the professional staff in the lovely CEA. The dining room is classic and understated. The staff are courteous and knowledgable. We had the 'rendezvous' menu which was certainly enough food for us. We also...

The highlights were the monkfish that looked like a garden, the lamb with Indian spices and the 'fishpond' dessert. Every course came on specific crockery and no detail was overlooked.  This is an expensive restaurant but worth every cent. We were also appreciative of the chef coming out to see if we enjoyed the meal - and the copy of what we ate and drank detailed in a scroll for us to take home.  A great experience of Madrid and Spain.

The main, main course of lamb was sensational and the final pudding, a "faux" hard boiled egg, definitely was the grand finale. This is Heston Blumenthal type cooking and, on the strength of this, I am going to make more effort to go and eat chez Blumenthal.

review_preview: Our lunch was sublime, maybe the most interesting I ever had.  The menu is quite creative, starting with the first teaser, which was the business card that was on the table when we arrived.  When the waiter brought out a pine nut oil mayonnaise and...
review_full: Our lunch was sublime, maybe the most interesting I ever had. The menu is quite creative, starting with the first teaser, which was the business card that was on the table when we arrived. When the waiter brought out a pine nut oil mayonnaise and told us it was for dipping the edible card, I was quite surprised (as it seems all the diners in our area of the restaurant). The sauce was excellent, the rice paper business card, tasted, well, sort of like a business card. This was followed by roughly ten more courses, each original and superb. We asked for wines by the glass and were treated to two excellent whites, both from Spain but quite different,then 2 great reds, followed by two interesting desert wines. The service was quite good, with almost everyone speaking excellent English. Although the food was not cheap, it was much less expensive than Michelin ** restaurants in Paris or US, and the wines were very reasonable. I really need to come back for dinner (although the lunch and dinner menus are the same choice of 3 tasting menus for the table). Overall, an unforgettable experience.

The two succulent:  1. taco arabe - toasted flat bread covered with grilled lamb laid over a touch of tzatziki-esquee sauce plus a bit of a red chili sauce 2. gobernador - small grilled shrimp mixed with a curious Mexican cheese dusted with kikos The repeater: taco de pez de mantequilla - grilled white fish glazed with a smoky paprika. Amazing! I would also strongly recommend starting out with the guacamole - fresh, a little chunky, yet creamy. The service was attentive, friendly and informative. The music was an ecclectic mix of soul, hip hop and mexo-jazz. Loved it! This place is very high on my list for upscale tacos.

review_preview: After three rather good dinners at the Principal Hotel restaurant Ático, I felt confident about booking the tasting menu for a birthday dinner there. Boy oh boy, what a mistake.We ended up with just average food, sloppy service and rather irritating wine pairings: at...
review_full: After three rather good dinners at the Principal Hotel restaurant Ático, I felt confident about booking the tasting menu for a birthday dinner there. Boy oh boy, what a mistake. We ended up with just average food, sloppy service and rather irritating wine pairings: at about half of the 6 course dinner the waiter simply told us the last wine would be repeated and proceeded to pour us the same white wine again. Given the positioning and pricing of this menu I found that incredibly offensive. We complained and they ended up giving us the coffee and water for free - again with an incredibly irritating waiter telling us „all is covered” and not accepting a tip. I thought this was almost offensive. The menu felt very rushed as we were forcefed through 6 courses in 1.5 hrs. Overall this place is stuck in a downward spiral and a mere shadow of the gem we found three years ago. Not recommended, I would look elsewhere given the pricepoint.

title_review: Such a memorable and great value experience
review_preview: On our arrival for a 5 day stay at The Principal hotel we enquired about bookings for the well-reviewed Atico and although very busy the concierge managed to book for 2 on the balcony on Sunday evening. We opted for the tasting menu with pairing,...
review_full: On our arrival for a 5 day stay at The Principal hotel we enquired about bookings for the well-reviewed Atico and although very busy the concierge managed to book for 2 on the balcony on Sunday evening. We opted for the tasting menu with pairing, the presentation of both augmented by the delightful service from Victor. A wonderfully balanced and designed 6 course selection of tuna, mango and avocado tartare, duck confit with foie gras and truffle, prawn trio, baked hake, roast Iberian suckling pig and melting chocolate sphere - this list reads much less special than the reality of the whole experience which was excellent value at 70 euros without the pairing. There is an added bonus of pre-dinner drinks on the Terrazo upstairs prior to further savoring the Madrid skyline view when you move to your recommended balcony table.

review_preview: A very quirky meal, the most interesting and inventive we've eaten in Madrid.  A mussel shell made of chocolate and silver...a dessert puffing out clouds....a very nice fish course followed by a very nice meat course.  Stunned by white chocolate eggshell covering real boiled egg...
review_full: A very quirky meal, the most interesting and inventive we've eaten in Madrid. A mussel shell made of chocolate and silver...a dessert puffing out clouds....a very nice fish course followed by a very nice meat course. Stunned by white chocolate eggshell covering real boiled egg [did I really want a boiled egg at that stage in the meal?] Lovely wine. Service superb, as it needed to be as we had to be told what to eat [everything]. Wouldn't have thought some things were edible otherwise. We ate the small menu which was enough for us. The other 2 menus are basically the same with more dishes, so would be good if you had a really big appetite. Lovely bread. It's the meal I shall always remember in Spain. Not to be missed!

review_preview: Undoubtedly good food — it’s well made, and of an interesting variety. Friendly staff and great cocktails! However,  when I order ‘interesting, new things’ I’m usually hoping for a bit of ‘umph’ in the flavours, especially with mexican food, and that was lacking a little...
review_full: Undoubtedly good food — it’s well made, and of an interesting variety. Friendly staff and great cocktails! However, when I order ‘interesting, new things’ I’m usually hoping for a bit of ‘umph’ in the flavours, especially with mexican food, and that was lacking a little here. The specialty dishes boasted an array of unorthodox ingredients, but they were still a bit ‘anonymous’ in terms of the flavours. Everything kind of just tasted like, well, good mexican food, but nothing really stood out in its flavour-profile, which is what I was hoping for, personally.  One disclaimer though — we had some very flavourful cocktails before the meal, which Did have a bit of ‘umph’ to them, so that might have taken everything after it down a notch.  I’d come back, for sure.

review_preview: My husband and I were tired after touring so we decided to eat at the hotel. They were booked but found a way to accommodate us. The concierge had told us the chef had 2 Michelin stars. I don’t usually like hotel restaurants but this...
review_full: My husband and I were tired after touring so we decided to eat at the hotel. They were booked but found a way to accommodate us. The concierge had told us the chef had 2 Michelin stars. I don’t usually like hotel restaurants but this one was superb. We only had main courses and dessert as we were tired and promised to be out quickly. I had the sea bass and my husband had the chicken tikka masala. Both were excellent. The desserts, Creme Caramel and the lollipop cakes with toffee sauce, were also very good.  The service was great and the prizes reasonable for that quality of a meal. We would highly recommend Atico. But book ahead!

review_preview: I'd done my reseach on finding a nice restaurant for me and the missus. We chose Atico from reviews and thought we'd have a nice view etc.On showing up, we were early so we were asked if we wanted a cocktail while waiting. We...
review_full: I'd done my reseach on finding a nice restaurant for me and the missus. We chose Atico from reviews and thought we'd have a nice view etc. On showing up, we were early so we were asked if we wanted a cocktail while waiting. We sat and enjoyed a very nice drink. After 15 mins, we were led to our table. We were placed right by a wall so already we thought why so many talk about a fantastic view. Maybe its not during dinner. More lunch but I don't know so that was a slight let down. We chose our starter and mains and I noticed our cocktails that we left behind (part of the service) was taken to the wrong table. I waved to say they were ours. Chose the wine was was lovely. We did notice that staff were rushing around a bit. As if there was a hurry to serve. I've been to many fine dining restaurants and I believe in a slower pace. Enjoy your food and drink without feeling rushed.  Starter came out and we were given the wrong plates. Not a problem but still another slight error. We ate our starters which were lovely. I had octopus and my girlfriend, duck. Both very nice. Once we finished, the main was out within 5 mins. Rather quick for us. During this time I asked for more bread. It never came. I also asked for more olive oil. I had to ask twice. Not what I come to expect when you're paying a lot of money. Mains came out. Both lovely. I had the lamb shank and the missus, pork. Once finished, the table was cleared. We waited for the desert menu. We waited and waited. People around us who came after us were on their deserts so Ihad to ask after 15 mins for a desert menu. By this time we weren't happy. If the service was slower and you could slowly enjoy the occasion, I would of bought another bottle of wine but we just wanted to leave. We were even undercharged. We're honest people so pointed out we were charged for two glasses of wine rather than a bottle. I'm sure other people have had a amazing time here but for us, we wouldn't go back. Sorry.

review_preview: The kitchen is directed by Ramón Freixa, a Catalan chef now resident in Madrid, so the focus is on Mediterranean style dishes with a contemporary twist. Advertised as a day-to-day type cuisine from this Michelin star winning chef (for Ramón Freixa Mardid) the food here...
review_full: The kitchen is directed by Ramón Freixa, a Catalan chef now resident in Madrid, so the focus is on Mediterranean style dishes with a contemporary twist. Advertised as a day-to-day type cuisine from this Michelin star winning chef (for Ramón Freixa Mardid) the food here does not disappoint, everything I ordered was superb and matched by an excellent service which is friendly and efficient. The highlight was the Calamar main course which was plate-licking good. Also the dessert, a flan served in a jar with several other complimentary tastes all going on at the same time. And it goes without saying that the name here gives a great clue to the views from the restaurant over the rooftops of central Madrid.

review_preview: I stayed at the Principal for a couple days and thought it would be great to try the restaurant on premise. The attention from the time you walk in was comforting. It is quaint and you can choose to dine inside or out on the...
review_full: I stayed at the Principal for a couple days and thought it would be great to try the restaurant on premise. The attention from the time you walk in was comforting.  It is quaint and you can choose to dine inside or out on the terrace.  I had the steak tartare which was nice,y prepared with a great sauce as a compliment. It was dressed with varying types of potato chips on top. Interesting.  My favorite thing of the night however was the flan. The outpouring of flavors literally melted in my mouth. Never tasted flan sooo good. The nuts, the caramel infused with the other spices. Not overwhelming.....Just darn good.  I also tried the rooftop ....La Terraza and the drinks and ambiance were great.i outed for the margarita which was nicely done.  Thanks to Esperanza and the entire Principal Team for being so gracious. From making my reservations to daily suggestions.  Hope to see you soon.

review_preview: With Ramon Freixa overseeing this restaurant we expected better. I went with my wife for lunch and started with an amuse bouche, followed by Spanish ham croquettes, potato ravioli filled with manet prawns in a piquant sauce. My wife had for main course pressed chicken...
review_full: With Ramon Freixa overseeing this restaurant we expected better. I went with my wife for lunch and started with an amuse bouche, followed by Spanish ham croquettes, potato ravioli filled with manet prawns in a piquant sauce. My wife had for main course pressed chicken with eel accompanied by apple, and I had steak tartare with crisps. We had one dessert to share which was chocolate with salt and olive oil. The bread served with the meal was very good-fresh and tasty. We both had a glass of wine from a list of around 6 choices covering white, rose, and red, in addition to mineral water and one coffee. The bill was €76 so represented fairly good value for money; and the view from the Terrace pleasant and interesting, and the ambience cosy. Verdict on the food: my wife didn't like the croquettes-there are better examples in some other restaurants in Madrid-nor her main course. My main course was reasonably good and properly seasoned, although hot french fries rather than a kind of crisp would have been preferred. The chocolate dessert was good but not exceptional. Service was professional. Overall our experience was slightly disappointing, but if our expectations had not been so high we would have probably rated it 4 instead of 3-

Simple gesture, but a nice touch.  Thoroughly recommended.

review_preview: My wife and I went here during our one night stay in Madrid during our honeymoon.  It is definitely off the beaten path and honestly I felt like we were lost while trying to find it. Thank goodness for phone GPS because we might not...
review_full: My wife and I went here during our one night stay in Madrid during our honeymoon. It is definitely off the beaten path and honestly I felt like we were lost while trying to find it. Thank goodness for phone GPS because we might not have found it otherwise. This is in no way a complaint more of an observation.  We had a great meal and it felt a little strange coming all the way to Madrid only to eat Mexican food but we are sure glad we did. We absolutely love Mexican food back home so off we went looking for this place. We made reservations online and upon arrival we found a table set up for us with our name on it already which was a very nice touch that we haven't seen before.  The workers were all very friendly and helpful. We started out with the nachos which were amazing! Both of our entrees were very good as were the margaritas. We also finished with a mousse dessert which was great. My only complaint was around towards the end of the meal the service slowed considerably. This might be the busy go fast American style of eating vs the more relaxed slow pace meals the locals are used to. It did take a little while to get our check but it wasn’t the end of the world.  I highly recommend this place for anyone looking for a great Mexican meal

title_review: Pricey but is totally worth for a special occasion
review_preview: We were quietly celebrating our marriage there on our wedding day. Just the two of us. The restaurant is really special in every aspect: the interior, the views, the service and last but definitely not least, food quality. It's a high-end place but nobody pushes...
review_full: We were quietly celebrating our marriage there on our wedding day. Just the two of us. The restaurant is really special in every aspect: the interior, the views, the service and last but definitely not least, food quality. It's a high-end place but nobody pushes you to order the pricey food. We were not very hungry with my wife when we arrived there for our reservation and just wanted this evening to be special. Just a starter and the main dish to share was enough for us to enjoy it and nobody pushed (as it happens in a lot of places in Spain) us to get more or more expensive food. What we had was exceptionally delicious! But then we had desert… I would have that flan again any time even if I'm completely full.

title_review: Excellent interesting and varied Mexican food.  Great service.
review_preview: Fancied a Mexican meal on last night in Madrid.  Chose Chamana from numerous Mexican restaurants and very pleased we did. The restaurant is informal and relaxed and the wait staff exceptionally friendly and helpful.  I'm usually disappointed with UK efforts at Mexican style food, but...
review_full: Fancied a Mexican meal on last night in Madrid. Chose Chamana from numerous Mexican restaurants and very pleased we did. The restaurant is informal and relaxed and the wait staff exceptionally friendly and helpful. I'm usually disappointed with UK efforts at Mexican style food, but not here. The food is a million miles away from standard tex mex fare. Chicken Tostadas were excellent - well spiced chicken with very fresh herbs and vegetable toppings. Also superb value for money. A Chicken Manchamantel main was equally tasty with a blend between mildly spiced sauce and grilled fresh fruits - A very different and enjoyable dish. There is a good selection of draft and bottled beer. We had a very good bottle of white wine that was also very reasonably priced. Overall this may be the best Mexican food i've tasted and I would recommend highly.

title_review: What a way to celebrate being 50!
review_preview: All of the previous positive reviews are valid.  It is an experience.  We had the sense to find the place the day before when we were in the area which I would suggest, as it is not too easy to find.  We were greeted and...
review_full: All of the previous positive reviews are valid. It is an experience. We had the sense to find the place the day before when we were in the area which I would suggest, as it is not too easy to find. We were greeted and seated in a beautiful old, high ceilinged dining room. The service was good, our waiter's English was not perfect which made understanding what each course a little tricky. But then it is a Spanish restaurant and I would like to see most waiters in Britain explaining intricate courses in Spanish!! It is artistic, impressive, beautiful and with many taste experiences. We had the largest menu (probably because we didn't want to miss out on anything/we are greedy!) and it was possibly too much. Not because of the quantity (which was perfectly adequate for 16 courses!) but for the richness of it all. I wish I had pushed for the sommelier to suggest a different wine with each few courses, as people seem to have done on this, but nervousness and lack of direct communication from me prevented this. The sommelier was excellent though and we ended up with a beautiful wine, that did not break the bank. In fact the whole meal for 2 of us came in at about £230 including wine which I think was incredibly good value.

review_preview: I have been waiting for an opportunity to justify the large expenditure required for a meal in this restaurant. When said opportunity appeared, I grabbed it by the lapels. Bottom line: totally worth it! A luxury meal generates expectations, forged through other meals and our...
review_full: I have been waiting for an opportunity to justify the large expenditure required for a meal in this restaurant. When said opportunity appeared, I grabbed it by the lapels. Bottom line: totally worth it! A luxury meal generates expectations, forged through other meals and our forward-looking fantasies and desires. When I walk into a luxury restaurant, I want to be surprised and pleased, in a balance of comfort and familiarity with surprise and why not, thrill. El Club Allard (ECA) delivers all that in large amounts. Chef María Marta del Rosario displays flair and respect for the ingredient, with the right sprinkling of irony and trompe l'oeil. My friend and I went for the complete menu, all 14 dishes from snacks to petit fours. It took a good three hours in which we were really taken by the food, with the environment to match, and a solid service, although occasionally peppered with slightly flippant attitudes. What a wonderful parade! Maria Marte's universe is a playground of textures, colors and flavors that amuse, excite and fascinate. Some memorable dishes were a pigeon and foie gras truffle in a cloud of eucaliptus smoke, an egg with potato and bacon bonbon, a sardine in turnip puree, a concentrated butterfish broth "shot" with salmon roe toast and a dessert of chocolate "rocks". A fantastic dinner, one of the best I had in 30 years of eating in 40 countries spread over four continents. Find YOUR reason to go to EAC, and go. Go soon.

title_review: Creative, fresh and enjoyable lunch experience
review_preview: The first thing you need to do is find the entrance to El Club Allard. We walked past the grand, imposing doors of the restaurant without even knowing it. But once we realised, we were shown into a lovely corridor which looked like we were...
review_full: The first thing you need to do is find the entrance to El Club Allard. We walked past the grand, imposing doors of the restaurant without even knowing it. But once we realised, we were shown into a lovely corridor which looked like we were guests in an exclusive villa. The waiter who served us had a slight arrogance about him but seemed to gradually warm up and was even humorous at times. Ambience of the restaurant was elegant but relaxed with plenty of natural light. Now the food itself was just splendid, my favourite is still the seafood platter (steaming fresh prawn, razor clams, clams grilled to perfection) with a twist served on a mini stone bbq with 3 different types of oils in syringes. But the dish with the most wow-factor has to be the first course being none other than the menu itself - the words intricately printed with squid ink and completely edible, of course only after you have decided on your courses. Other highlights included the lobster (again perfectly cooked), icy foie gras shavings which melted in your mouth, caviar infused cherry and desserts, although I thought the fish bowl which looked a little sloppy and I wasn't a big fan of the yoghurt base (although I loved the red 'fronds'). Nothing better than to finish up with 'chocolate rocks' and a passionfruit flavoured chalk. Overall I found the flavours complemented each other especially the creative appetizers. The 4 of us spent about 580 euro including a bottle of wine which is reasonable value for this calibre of dining so it was well worth the experience.

title_review: Ático restaurant - what a big disappointment
review_preview: After having an outstanding experience at the restaurant Unico, by Chef Ramon Freixa , we decided to celebrate on 15/11/ 2018 the 50th birthday of a dear friend at the atico Restaurant. The disappointment was from the first moment, they let me wait a long...
review_full: After having an outstanding experience at the restaurant Unico, by Chef Ramon Freixa , we decided to celebrate on 15/11/ 2018 the 50th birthday of a dear friend at the atico Restaurant. The disappointment was from the first moment, they let me wait a long time, until someone approached me, asking my name for the reservation. We ordered a “ Degustación menu “ with a matching wine list, the food was mediocre and down, just not tasty, a difference of day and night from the wonderful meal I experienced at the Unico Restaurant, the service was very clumsy. In addition to that , I asked for something to mark the 50th birthday of my dear friend, It is true I called only 6 hours before we arrived to the restaurant, what we got was : at the end of the meal we were served another glass of sweet wine for dessert for the birthday, it was simply insulting !! Even a small fire refining could have done the job. For a chef's meal with a cost of nearly 200 euros, the disappointment was very big !! I am sure that if Chef Ramón Freixa was there, he would be very ashamed of the food that was served to us by his name. NavaLee  Sent from my iPhone

title_review: Don't judge a book by its cover!
review_preview: We visited this restaurant after reading other reviews on TripAdvisor. To be honest, had we not done so we most probably would've walked by. It's an unassuming restaurant from the exterior but that doesn't matter when the food is as good as it was. We...
review_full: We visited this restaurant after reading other reviews on TripAdvisor. To be honest, had we not done so we most probably would've walked by. It's an unassuming restaurant from the exterior but that doesn't matter when the food is as good as it was. We were welcomed in and sat at the window next to the door. Tables and chairs are wooden, pretty old and probably not the comfiest but that just adds to its charm in my opinion. We ordered 3 dishes and a bottle of Rioja (the fried anchovies were a particular favourite). 3 dishes might not sound a great amount when talking about tapas however these were huge in comparison to your standard UK alternative. Total cost was €24. The food was faultless, cooked fresh, delicious! The wine was enjoyable too. Overall a great find and had it not been for our short stay we would've returned without a doubt!

review_preview: The food is exceptional to say the least! The Seduction menu which I had, introduced many layers of flavors and textures into each dish, and they all came together well to tease my curiosity into wonderment. Not only were my taste buds tempted beyond human...
review_full: The food is exceptional to say the least! The Seduction menu which I had, introduced many layers of flavors and textures into each dish, and they all came together well to tease my curiosity into wonderment. Not only were my taste buds tempted beyond human restraint, visuals and smells were all impressive.  The placard at the start of the meal was made of Japanese rice paper and printed with squid ink - and when the waiter told me it could be eaten, I thought he was joking! Therein started my culinary journey and every single appetizer/course was a pleasant surprise. The chef used flavors from all over - Asia to Latin American etc - which showcased his/her top notch knowledge and hands-on experience with these ingredients. Nothing experimental but certainly the ingredients were all well matched with each other. Apart from culinary enjoyment, it was a test of my food knowledge as well! Without giving away the many delectable encounters I had here, I would divulge my experience with the desserts. Petals, was rose mousse encased in white chocolate encrusted with dried rose petals - the embodiment of subtle sweetness and lightness. All these were balanced with Granny Smith sorbet and lychee cream. The riot of colors in front me, the faint whiff of rose and light sweetness on my tongue made it thoroughly unforgettable. The different textures, the various co-mingled flavors - wow, just exceeded my expectations on how one can deal with a rose flavored dessert!  Wow, again.

title_review: I'm dreading others finding out about this place
review_preview: In business for some 30 years I believe, this neighbourhood Japanese restaurant is on a pretty dingy street, with only a door and a neon sign marking it.  Blink and you'll miss it.  My third visit, and better than ever.  We arrived at 10:15 on...
review_full: In business for some 30 years I believe, this neighbourhood Japanese restaurant is on a pretty dingy street, with only a door and a neon sign marking it. Blink and you'll miss it. My third visit, and better than ever. We arrived at 10:15 on a week night, knowing they were fully booked (that's fully booked twice over - they have a first and second sitting), but praying a table might come free. We loitered until 11, and were given the last table - having been here before I knew it would be worth waiting for. This is the place to try some of the more unusual things on the menu, confident that they will be well executed. The raw egg/fermented soya bean/chopped raw tuna dish was to DIE for - the lady serving us checked that we liked unusual flavours when I ordered it. Agree with previous reviewers that this is probably the best Japanese food you'll find in Madrid, without paying through the nose for something much more 'haute'. The service is gracious and helpful. If you want a table where you sit on the floor, ask, as they have a few - similarly, say so if you want to sit at the bar or at a regular table. And reserve a spot earlier in the day as the restaurant is always busy. As I say, I dread telling people to go here, in case I can't then get a table when I'm in town!

review_preview: This was an amazing place to go to for tapas and drinks! While we waited at the the bar to get seated, we got to interact with the most amazing bartender ever -- Peter Hernandez. We started out just ordering drinks at the bar, but...
review_full: This was an amazing place to go to for tapas and drinks! While we waited at the the bar to get seated, we got to interact with the most amazing bartender ever -- Peter Hernandez. We started out just ordering drinks at the bar, but it was so nice sitting there that we had our meal there too and forgot about getting a table! The sangria is amazing and is a must try here. We saw the bartender make at least 30 of those delicious drinks served in mason jar like glasses. Apparently they serve over a hundred sangrias every night :O The service at Taberna El Sur is spectacular -- I got a second sangria on the house, and the bartender even brought us two shots of a baileys-like drink at the end of our meal! We left feeling so special and happy :)  About the food -- the tapas and main courses are really tasty and well portioned. We got the moussaka, patatas bravas, spanish omelette and a chilled tomato soup (all the tapas but the quiche basically) and each one was a star! I am trying to pick a favorite, but I really can't pick between the moussaka and the patatas bravas, both of which were unforgettable! We also got a chicken curry that was great.  Overall, if you are in the area or even close by, Taberna El Sur is definitely worth your time and money! Go there, and I hope you have as great a time as we did eating, drinking and enjoying being in Madrid!  PS. There's no problem if you don't know Spanish, the menu is in English and the staff are all very tourist friendly. The prices are great too!

It's crazy, but amazingly good crazy. Stunning food, stupid prices, a bit up itself, but did I mention that the food is stunning? Well, the food is stunning!! Don't expect more than a mouthful or 2 per dish, but do savour the beauty, flavour, texture and overall creativity of it, before laughing out loud at the 'emperors' new clothes' type of attitude that pervades. It's not really a restaurant, it's a show, an art gallery and a tasty fairytale rolled into one. Now I'm hoping to wake up and find that the bill was just a fairytale too.................

review_preview: Prepared to be impressed. It is a feast for all the senses. Colours, flavours, odours, textures all combined harmoniously to deliver the perfect food which tantalises the palate to the extreme.The restaurant is housed in a rococo building that impresses architecturally even the most...
review_full: Prepared to be impressed. It is a feast for all the senses. Colours, flavours, odours, textures all combined harmoniously to deliver the perfect food which tantalises the palate to the extreme. The restaurant is housed in a rococo building that impresses architecturally even the most demanding connoisseur and is in contrast with the interior of the restaurant deemed to be minimalist in style but welcoming at the same time. There is no menu. The Chef cooks the same for every body the night you visit the restaurant, the only variation is how many dishes you want to try. Of course there is a prior consultation with the client regarding allergies and likes and dislikes. Keep in mind this is not a normal restaurant where you eat a steak and fries. This is a place where a secret teasing of your appetite and senses is taking place and the element of the surprise and the unexpected comes in the game often. What you see and eat is art in every sense. Be prepared to receive the visit of the chef at the end of your meal who wants to know the opinion of the clients at the end of the dinner. Service excellent. Not to be missed. Reserve well in advance.

review_preview: You need time if you want to have lunch (or dinner) at El Club Allard (and as is customary in Spain, lunch starts late - earliest reservation is at 1:30 PM). But it is worth the wait and worth the time spent at the table....
review_full: You need time if you want to have lunch (or dinner) at El Club Allard (and as is customary in Spain, lunch starts late - earliest reservation is at 1:30 PM). But it is worth the wait and worth the time spent at the table. Incredibly innovative and imaginative cuisine in 12 or more courses (if you go for the Menu Revolucion) at very reasonable prices (relatively speaking; I say that as someone coming from San Francisco where you can easily drop 1,200 bucks for dinner for two with wine at a place like Saison). Even though the original chef Diego Guerrero is no longer in charge (the kitchen is now in the extremely skilled hands of Maria Marte) things are still exceptional at this true temple for foodies. Truly one of the best meals I have ever had and I have had many...

review_preview: .....is offered in this two star etablissement. Very nice interior with excellent food. They offer three different surprise menus (85, 98, 115 Euros) and they ask you if you have food allergies or some food you wouldn't like. You will get a print out of...
review_full: .....is offered in this two star etablissement. Very nice interior with excellent food. They offer three different surprise menus (85, 98, 115 Euros) and they ask you if you have food allergies or some food you wouldn't like. You will get a print out of the menu at the end of the evening - not before so ! The wine list is dominated -for obvious reasons- by spanish wines but they have decent french, italian, new world as well - and it is very reasonable priced ! The food was sometimes surprising but always prefect quality and very delicious. Unfortunately I have to cut off one star because of the service, which was lacking real passion. Not really unfriendly but the waiter was bored and rushed us through the menu. He made the dinner a little bit unpleasant !

title_review: Warm, helpful staff with an interesting menu
review_preview: We were seated at 8:30 p.m. on the dot. (As U.S. citizens we eat much earlier than the locals.) The white wine by the glass was delicious and the waitress helped me select it. She presented us with a spectacular gazpacho in a small cup...
review_full: We were seated at 8:30 p.m. on the dot. (As U.S. citizens we eat much earlier than the locals.) The white wine by the glass was delicious and the waitress helped me select it. She presented us with a spectacular gazpacho in a small cup and bread with an olive oil whipped cream. (I think that's what it was.) I wish we could have had more! My first course (roasted tomatoes with mackerel) was absolutely divine. I would order it again and recommend it. My second course was a rice dish with one red prawn and four pieces of ham. It wasn't remarkable. The ambiance is nice but the music needs work. We stayed in the Principal Hotel so we would have breakfast in the same area as the restaurant and enjoy the bar before dinner. The same song playlist is on loop and has been for the entire time we have been there. I believe we listened to Piano Man twice while dining at Atico. It is details like this that set the 5 star restaurants apart. That being said, this is a nice place to eat.

title_review: Cool place with some outstanding dishes
review_preview: The place is really cool, whether you sit indoor or at the terrace. To start we shared an appetizer the Surf and Turf Coca I would say it was good but not what I was expecting specially in terms of the portion and the simplicity...
review_full: The place is really cool, whether you sit indoor or at the terrace. To start we shared an appetizer the Surf and Turf Coca I would say it was good but not what I was expecting specially in terms of the portion and the simplicity of the dish. I had the Duck Cannelloni with Foie as main course and it was brilliant. They have a good wine list, with prices for all budgets and a good selection. Dessert was also amazing we had the Milk-Cocoa-Hazelnut, you can request to have it in the glass terrace which has AC and overlooks the Metropolis Building it's really worth it. The only caveat would be the service, the waiter was unfriendly and seemed annoyed to answer any questions, however when they changed shifts we had a lovely waitress.
