review_preview: Very disappointed with the food - the presentation was beautiful and clever at times, but the taste was nothing special. I would describe the food as a science experiment - with foam! First course was the menu printed with squid ink on a wafer -...
review_full: Very disappointed with the food - the presentation was beautiful and clever at times, but the taste was nothing special. I would describe the food as a science experiment - with foam! First course was the menu printed with squid ink on a wafer - that was just funny, but once the other courses started coming, we lost our sense of humor. There was 2 inch piece of fish that would have tasted fine except it was covered with an inch of foam made out of fish bone marrow - it had a very fishy taste. One course was cherry soup with a whole cherry stuffed with caviar instead of the cherry pit (I think the waiter said it was a herring caviar - not the good stuff). I understand that its hard to stuff a cherry with caviar, but why would you want to? it does not taste good, though the soup was not bad. The best course was the truffle in a bowl of smoke - this was a pate ball. The only meat was a pigeon, that wasn't bad either. The desert - we had 2 courses: 1 was swimming in rose flavored concoction that no one could eat - at this point even the real foodies among stopped saying this was "interesting", not tasty - interesting. The second looked like chocolate cake but was not at all sweet, then, with coffee, there were wafers or cookies that looked like letters and chalk served on a blackboard - clever but not sweet and not tasty.  The whole experience was pretentious, from a waiter who pretended to smile by showing teeth, to the multiple tiny courses that were artistic and pretended to be food, but did not taste like anything special. Even the foodies among our 3 couples felt this was an "interesting" experience, the rest of us just thought it was funny and sad by turns. For 400+ dollars per couple, you can definitely have a much better dining experience in Madrid.

review_preview: It is difficult to define what an excellent restaurant should have. Everybody, at certain point, could easily differentiate a nice place and/or an enjoyable meal from an ugly location, a terrible service or a tasteless food. However, from “nice” to “excellent”, there is a slight...
review_full: It is difficult to define what an excellent restaurant should have.  Everybody, at certain point, could easily differentiate a nice place and/or an enjoyable meal from an ugly location, a terrible service or a tasteless food. However, from “nice” to “excellent”, there is a slight and always subjective line difficult to define.  Club Allard has a very good service (considering the Spanish standards). Its wine list is comprehensive and covers from the middle to the high-end wines of Europe and some “new-world” vineyards. Nevertheless, the food is a different topic. The restaurant only serves testing menus and they are renewed each season. It is not traditional place (you will not find the typical Spanish dishes or the “tapas” ambiance) and, certainly, I would not suggest bringing kinds. For those who want just a fancy dinner, Club Allard may be “excessive”. But, if you are the kind of person that likes to explore new flavors and challenge your own pre-conceptions about some ingredients, this is an ideal place.

Having been to another 2 michelin star restaurant in madrid that I was very, very disappointed with, this restaurant has reinstalled my confidence in the standard required in order...
review_full: Having just left this restaurant all I can say is.......amazing! Truly fantastic food, service and ambience. Having been to another 2 michelin star restaurant in madrid that I was very, very disappointed with, this restaurant has reinstalled my confidence in the standard required in order to achieve michelin standards in madrid. This restaurant was easily on par with London michelin restaurants and very well priced for this level of food. At the end of the meal the chef was introduced which was a lovely touch especially being able to thank them in person. Love, love, love this restaurant ( especially the 'Nemo' dessert which was incredible ) if you appreciate fine dining, you have to visit this restaurant, it's an absolute must. Thank you to all the staff which made tonight a wonderful experience and most definitely the highlight of our weekend ( special thanks to our waiter for speaking 'Spanglish' as my spanish is not the best! ) Fantastic night.

title_review: Last and best dinner in Madrid
review_preview: We have visited Atico restaurant which is located on 6th floor of The Principal hotel during our last night. We already stopped by in the afternoon as we wanted to have a coffee in their roof terrace but we were informed it was without service...
review_full: We have visited Atico restaurant which is located on 6th floor of The Principal hotel during our last night. We already stopped by in the afternoon as we wanted to have a coffee in their roof terrace but we were informed it was without service and closed in low season. So we returned for dinner. The Atico restaurant is small so I highly recommend reservation which we didn´t have done but we were seated.  The place is very comfortable and the staff is amazing....very helpful and tentative. As a main course I got Tuna top loin with citrus fruits and blintzes and my friend Crunchy socarrat rice with duck and Norway lobster. I do not like ducks but my friends meal was so delicious that my fork was constantly in his plate. But my tuna (tataki) was delicious as well.  Then we got coffee on their lovely roof terrace...however it was without service they allowed us to enter for coffee. And finished dinner with couple of drinks in their bar. We enjoyed this our last Madrid dinner very much and if returned to Madrid we would definitely come back.

review_preview: Atico is a restaurant concern of double Michelin Star chef Ramon Freixa and situated on the 6th floor of the 5 star Principal hotel just off the Calle de Alcala in central Madrid. My wife and I decided to give it a go because the...
review_full: Atico is a restaurant concern of double Michelin Star chef Ramon Freixa and situated on the 6th floor of the 5 star Principal hotel just off the Calle de Alcala in central Madrid. My wife and I decided to give it a go because the menu, to us at least, looked delicious and far preferable to his two star offering. We took the lift to the 6th floor and were greeted warmly by the staff. I factored in some time to have a drink on the terrace before having our lunch. (Top Tip: Lunch time in Spain is very likely to give you a better experience than the evening) The terrace is delightful and provides a relaxing precursor to the main event. The bar is well supplied and they know how to serve a good drink.  The restaurant has a classy, calm and relaxing environment and it's a welcome relief from hustle and bustle of Madrid. We begin events with a selection of croquetas and they are excellent, among the best I've ever had. We both settled for the 'Salad of Contrasts' and it is a quality and refreshing start. For mains I had 'hake baked at low temperature' and my wife had 'tuna loin with citrus fruits.' Both very good indeed and we know we are in a good restaurant. I chose a good bottle of El Hobre Bala from the Madrid region from a decent wine list. The desert selection is surprisingly good for Spain and we chose 'exotic fruits with aged rum'  I have to add that the staff were exceptionally attentive, courteous and friendly throughout. We've been to Madrid many times (my wife is Spanish - Castilian) and this is one of our best dining experiences we've had and possibly the best value meal when the quality is taken into consideration. We tend to eat more modestly but if you fancy something a upmarket, without Michelin miniaturisation or Madrid tourist trap this is a very firm recommendation.

review_preview: I was staying at the Principal Madrid so decided to try the restaurant one night. They tout the fact that it is Ramón Freixa designed menu, but the connection to a 2 Michelin star chef (at his other restaurant) is not a fair one. Do...
review_full: I was staying at the Principal Madrid so decided to try the restaurant one night. They tout the fact that it is Ramón Freixa designed menu, but the connection to a 2 Michelin star chef (at his other restaurant) is not a fair one. Do not expect that sort of quality here. The amuse bouche was actually very good. However beyond that I found the food thoroughly average. The croquetas de jamon were nothing special, you can get the same thing anywhere for half the price. My main course was the biggest offender though. I got the "Crunchy socarrat rice with duck and Norway lobster". There was absolutely nothing crunchy about the rice, at all, which is simply unacceptable for socarrat - that is the whole point of it! To have no crunch entirely defeats the dish and this was very disappointing. So overall I would say just not really worth it. Wait staff were good, no issues there, it was the food that disappointed. Madrid has many better options.

title_review: Nice relaxed evening with nice views very nice food and outstanding service
review_preview: We had a very nice dinner experience at the Restaurante Atico on the 6th floor of the Principal Hotel on the last night of our recent stay in Madrid. We read that the restaurant was highly rated and decided to give it a try. There...
review_full: We had a very nice dinner experience at the Restaurante Atico on the 6th floor of the Principal Hotel on the last night of our recent stay in Madrid. We read that the restaurant was highly rated and decided to give it a try. There is limited seating so you must book a day or more ahead and we did. We had a nice table with views across to the Metropolis and beyond on a clear night. The smaller size of the restaurant adds to its charm and assures that you are not forgotten.  The food was excellent. We enjoyed an octopus first corse, very well prepared fresh fish and a well prepared steak. We were helped to select an outstanding Spanish wine to accompany our meal and ended with a unique desert and matching wine to be capped off by an after dinner drink…as I said a very relaxing evening. The service could not have been any better, attentive, and helpful. We were allowed plenty of time to enjoy our meal but waited for nothing. This was a nice night for just the two of us…we made a good choice!

review_preview: We stayed at the Principal and decided to try this restaurant (which is on the 6th floor).  The chef has a Michelin starred (2) restaurant elsewhere in town, with this being one of his other efforts.  The food was delicious, the presentation was fun, and...
review_full: We stayed at the Principal and decided to try this restaurant (which is on the 6th floor). The chef has a Michelin starred (2) restaurant elsewhere in town, with this being one of his other efforts. The food was delicious, the presentation was fun, and the prices were extremely reasonable with items running from 8 to 20 Euros. Many of the dishes are fun interpretations and in some cases, the execution is a small surprise. We had the Potato salad appetizer (yum!), followed by the scallops (perfect!), with entrees of the Iberian Pork and the Salmon. Dessert was the "milk, sugar, etc." - ALL are recommended. Service was very attentive and top notch. Delicious!

title_review: We still talk fondly about El Club Allard! Sensational!
review_preview: Yes, it was difficult to find, but coming from Melbourne, where everything worthwhile is in an alleyway, and behind an unmarked/poorly signed entrance, El Club Allard is worth it!Unlikely other restaurants, where after a while, the degustation process can seem a bit tedious... every...
review_full: Yes, it was difficult to find, but coming from Melbourne, where everything worthwhile is in an alleyway, and behind an unmarked/poorly signed entrance, El Club Allard is worth it! Unlikely other restaurants, where after a while, the degustation process can seem a bit tedious... every course here was a delight, and your palate never felt jaded. The technique and expertise in every course was evident, but the chef's ultimate aim was to delight your tastebuds, and not to impress you with superfluous froths, foams and jellies (technique for technique's sake is a distressing malady in some many modern and expensive restaurants nowadays).  The food was always presented beautifully, some of it incredibly witty (our 'egg dessert' and the 'ocean floor' was outstanding).  We are planning our holiday for next year, and I must admit to being very tempted by a return to Madrid, if only to stop by El Club Allard for another delightful dinner.

review_preview: You have to go on a bit of a discovery tour to find El Sur, but it is worth the extra effort! You turn down a small side street and find it on a hidden corner. Once you walk in the atmosphere envelopes you of...
review_full: You have to go on a bit of a discovery tour to find El Sur, but it is worth the extra effort! You turn down a small side street and find it on a hidden corner. Once you walk in the atmosphere envelopes you of the real Madrid. Every one of the servers joins in to help make your meal satisfying. A good selection of wine and a very tasty Sangria concocted by the bartender satisfied our thirsts after walking the streets of Madrid all day. (The best Sangria I enjoyed in Madrid!) Many locals filled the place, but that did not stop them from giving us the same first class experience. When Gustavo Montero came by to make sure all was well, we discovered why everything worked together so well. He took care of all the details, including watering the plants. We enjoyed the shrimp, pork tenderloins and salads. Gustavo came by with a treat for dessert - a very sumptuous cheese cake. The evening was capped off with free Spanish Crema! We loved it so much, we went back for lunch the next day and enjoyed it all again. Special thanks to Henry for his service too.

title_review: a real foodie  adventure in Madrid
review_preview: a small and charming restaurant located on the 6th floor of the principal hotel in Madrid. The service was possibly the best we had in all of Spain. a very interesting variety  of dishes that I have never eaten in my entire life. I tried...
review_full: a small and charming restaurant located on the 6th floor of the principal hotel in Madrid. The service was possibly the best we had in all of Spain. a very interesting variety of dishes that I have never eaten in my entire life. I tried all four of the courses on the menu. I started out with the croquettes, a combination of seafood croquettes and a ham and mushroom version. They were excellent. Next came the octopus tentacle with black squid ink on a bed of crushed potatoes. muy delicioso. the main course was a duck and Norwegian lobster dish on crunchy rice served in a mini paella pan. Very tasty. Dessert was a chocolate dish called Ole' Ole'. Layers of deep rich chocolate topped off with a light fluffy chocolate mousse in a tall shot glass. this was possibly one of the best meals that we have eaten in a long time. Also, the prices were extremely reasonable compared to what we paid for lesser meals in other dining venues around Madrid. octopus tentacle, pictured below.

review_preview: I was taken here as a surprise during a weekend break to Madrid. We had the 'seduction' menu at lunchtime. Every single course was like a piece of art. The service  was great - not intrusive but explaining every dish (in English) so we knew...
review_full: I was taken here as a surprise during a weekend break to Madrid. We had the 'seduction' menu at lunchtime. Every single course was like a piece of art. The service was great - not intrusive but explaining every dish (in English) so we knew what we were eating (as you couldn't always tell by looking at them!). Highlights were the desserts (pre-dessert was very refreshing and cleansed your palate, the fishbowl was beautiful and the 'egg' was so clever!) and the foie gras and truffle starter. We asked for three glasses of wine to match the meal and these were lovely too.  My girlfriend and I didn't like one of the courses which had fish eggs in, but as part of the overall experience it was still an interesting dish, so no real complaints.  I would definitely recommend for anyone going to Madrid particularly for a special occasion. Not cheap but a fantastic experience and very memorable.

review_preview: Final night in Madrid/Spain with friends after a week in Malaga.  Outstanding dining experience and exclamation point to a great week in Spain.  Nice surprises starting with the business card and ending with the quirky "Finding Nemo."  Great to find a chef/restaurant that maintains a...
review_full: Final night in Madrid/Spain with friends after a week in Malaga. Outstanding dining experience and exclamation point to a great week in Spain. Nice surprises starting with the business card and ending with the quirky "Finding Nemo." Great to find a chef/restaurant that maintains a sense of humor and takes its food seriously without taking itself too seriously. This, after I had a pleasant but none-too-outstanding dinner at the French Laundry in Napa two weeks earlier. This experience was much better value for the money. Staff is very friendly and helpful. The sommelier produced two very nice wines at reasonable prices to accompany our courses. I'd have to say that the two fish dishes were a bit too large for the overall meal--but I didn't leave anything behind. I will return with my wife.

review_preview: What a lovely surprise this place was! We ordered the tuna special upon the waiter's recommendation and I would say that dish was of starred quality. Presentation was creative and the products were top quality.Other dishes we ordered included the soft shell crab, scarmoza...
review_full: What a lovely surprise this place was! We ordered the tuna special upon the waiter's recommendation and I would say that dish was of starred quality. Presentation was creative and the products were top quality. Other dishes we ordered included the soft shell crab, scarmoza raviolo, smoked sardine and corvina with truffle. Everything was exquisite. All the dishes were presented in a creative manner and I can honestly say it's unlike any other food I tried on my trip to Madrid.  The service was friendly and the wines are excellent - we had both red & white, each wine complemented the food perfectly which suggests they have a good sommelier.  If I'm being hyper-critical, there was a bit too much truffle with the corvina, which was a very intense flavour and overpowered the fish slightly. I also think that the pincho of smoked sardine with a tomato salsa and Burrata cheese would work better as two separate tapas as the cheese and sardine are delicious separately but are a bit too rich together.

title_review: Convenient, good food; but lacks a bit of atmosphrer
review_preview: Wanted a simple and relatively quick tapas meal in the evening. We were seated straight away and drinks orders taken quickly. Young waitress serving us was pleasant and spoke good English but didn't smile and just seemed a bit under pressure. It is part of...
review_full: Wanted a simple and relatively quick tapas meal in the evening. We were seated straight away and drinks orders taken quickly. Young waitress serving us was pleasant and spoke good English but didn't smile and just seemed a bit under pressure. It is part of a chain and has that feel. The food was good and a reasonable price and our first orders were served quite quickly. Took a bit of time to get a second drink and additional tapas but we weren't in any rush. Compared to another tapas restaurant we ate at the following night this was certainly more like a fast food place than gourmet; but to be fair the food quality was good and so was the price. I would eat here again but only out of convenience, not if I was looking for a special night out. Total price for two of us was E46.80 which included 2 x .5L beer and one .3l Plus 6 different tapas.

title_review: A great place to bring friends together
review_preview: Rayuela was the site of a wonderful birthday celebration I had recently. It is a truly charming restaurant located right next to the Puente de Segovia in la Latina and next to la Vistillas, in the historic centre of Madrid. I had the whole of...
review_full: Rayuela was the site of a wonderful birthday celebration I had recently. It is a truly charming restaurant located right next to the Puente de Segovia in la Latina and next to la Vistillas, in the historic centre of Madrid.  I had the whole of the downstairs to gather my friends. The space is beautiful, with stunning views of the bridge and parkland in this area; the staff were attentive; the service, gracious; the food was perfect. I would recommend Rayuela for any occasion: lunch or dinner (the dining room upstairs is charming); or a very special night out with friends. It is clear Nicolas, Isabelo & Nieves, alongside their wonderful waiters, know how to provide their guests with a quality evening I won't forget. Many thanks to you all x

review_preview: It was our last evening in Madrid, so I wanted something really special.  El Club Allard was at the top of the Trip Advisor list, so, of course, that was my choice.  It was spectacular! This was the first week in our six week vacation,...
review_full: It was our last evening in Madrid, so I wanted something really special. El Club Allard was at the top of the Trip Advisor list, so, of course, that was my choice. It was spectacular! This was the first week in our six week vacation, to include three other one star Michelin restaurants. Needless to say, this one topped the list! From the game truffle with foie and mushrooms, w/smoke to the grilled sea selection w/ essential oils, w/dry ice, to the peas and sardines w/celeriac cream & apple, to the cold cherry soup w/ herring caviar, to the egg w/bread and pancetta over light potato cream sauce, to the fish w/rhubarb chuttney and spring oinion, to the suckling lamb shoulder w/Tandoori crumble to the hibiscus flower w/Pisco sour to the fishbowl, chocolate rocks and blackboard - it was fun and exotic and delicious! It was everything we could have imagined! We would go back in a heartbeat and recommend it to all foodies.

title_review: Let your taste buds do the talking
review_preview: Book this restaurant for my birthday while vacationing in Madrid with friends.  I picked this restaurant based on TripAdvisor reviews.  This was the top choice on page 1 and I didn't even bother to look at page 2.  I had to say I made a...
review_full: Book this restaurant for my birthday while vacationing in Madrid with friends. I picked this restaurant based on TripAdvisor reviews. This was the top choice on page 1 and I didn't even bother to look at page 2. I had to say I made a very good choice. The food was not just amazing. It was creative and explosives. You could taste each ingredients but they never overpower one another. My friends of course later mentioned to our server that it was my birthday and toward the end they brought me this platter with sorbet over candy clam shelf and "happy birthday' in icing across the platter. The chef later on came out to greet us and is a "SHE" which really top the icing so to speak. The tasting menu is less than US$150 per person (the most expensive one) and let me said it is very reasonable compared to all the so call celebrity chefs we have in the US and even better. If you are foodie like me and my friends, you will enjoy this restaurant. If you are into steak and potatoes, this is not a place for you.

title_review: So pleased to have found this (relatively low-profile) gem
review_preview: The place, once you find it, is like a very smart apartment; small but beautifully decorated.  The atmosphere is quite formal but the staff are very friendly and the chef Diego Guerrero visits everyone to check they are ok, what they want etc - unusual...
review_full: The place, once you find it, is like a very smart apartment; small but beautifully decorated. The atmosphere is quite formal but the staff are very friendly and the chef Diego Guerrero visits everyone to check they are ok, what they want etc - unusual attention to detail and very impressive. A surprisingly reasonable wine list (sommelier recommended an excellent c.30 euro Albarino) and the tasting menus are also not too expensive. Very inventive food, molecular gastronomy which plenty of quirks and surprises. Good flavours and a good, long dining experience. Comfortably one of my favourite dining experiences, and one of the best value.

We also order the following drinks: Vaso Sangria Beer with lemon Fanta (Clara con Limon) The sangria came recommended by Alex, our waiter and the beer with lemon Fanta was a result of some research we had done on local drinks of Spain. Alex first looked at me funny when I asked for 1/2 beer 1/2 Fanta, but when I specified that I wanted lemon Fanta, he immediately realized what I was asking for and explained that it was referred to as Clara con Limon in Spanish. Overall, a solid dining experience, with the highlight being Alex's friendliness.

Choose from the about 50 menu items and get them served in 15 minutes. Just pick some items you might like and share them with your table! Tableservice is fast and good (during lunchtime it is not full) and quality of food is good and tastes well.  We took padron peppers, patatas bravas, iberico croquettes, solomillo burgers, fried pescadito ... The only not that tasty item was the pinchos morunos. I think this could have grilled longer and better.

As you enter you are greeted by very personable staff who take you to your table. From start to finish this can only be described as an excellent experience of food and art. The staff were amazing explaining each dish and how best to eat it and recommending excellent but decently priced wine. To be honest it was a piece if theatre that I would highly recommend to anyone to experience and the icing on the cake was meeting the chef Diego Guerrero and his team who were so gracious....thx all.

review_preview: Obviously, this place is well known as is the chef. We had the tasting menu. It worked out to be about $100 per person. Each dish was like a work of art, but also tasted flawless. Many dishes were such interesting combinations of flavor that...
review_full: Obviously, this place is well known as is the chef. We had the tasting menu. It worked out to be about $100 per person. Each dish was like a work of art, but also tasted flawless. Many dishes were such interesting combinations of flavor that I had not had before. Everything was cooked perfectly. Everything was fresh. Even a tiny little carrot in one dish tasted like the most potent and delicious carrot flavor I have had.  The service was perfect. They don't speak great English, but enough to get by for most of the servers.  It is hard to locate. It is on the corner and has a box outside that looks like you buzz into an apartment. No obvious signs except etched in the glass of the windows.  The Chef visited all the tables at the end of the meal to ask how things were and seemed to really care and take it personally.  The total bill was a little over $300 with Cava, a glass of Port, and coffee for my wife. It was well worth it. This place deserves its reputation and its two Michelin stars.

title_review: Best of the best in Madrid
review_preview: Club Allard was a very positive surprise in our home city. I wonder why I had not gone to this restaurant before. The tasting menu is absolutely flawless and the food has amazing taste, I think Diego Guerrero finds just the right balance between innovation...
review_full: Club Allard was a very positive surprise in our home city. I wonder why I had not gone to this restaurant before. The tasting menu is absolutely flawless and the food has amazing taste, I think Diego Guerrero finds just the right balance between innovation and cooking food that tastes to food (as opposed to many other chefs that call themselves followers of Adria and cook food that does not taste to food). All the dishes were delicious. There is no a la carte dining, you are offered three different tasting menu options, that vary in the number of dishes to taste and you are asked if you have any food alergies or dislikes. I must confess that I did not like the method so much when it was presented to me, but you have to trust the chef, because every dish that came out of the kitchen was absolutely delicious, both in execution and presentation. The dessert part of the dinner was especially interesting, some of the desserts that I tried are comparable to the ones taht you have in Arzak! Especially the fishbowl ("la pecera").  To me, the food of this restaurant deserves the third michelin star, I am afraid that it wont be long until it gets it and then we locals will have to wait more for reservations and pay more for the food!

title_review: Authentic cuisine, eclectic atmosphere, great value!
review_preview: Nestled away & easily unnoticed, don't be fooled by Casa Toni's exterior aesthetic, this humble restaurant epitomises authentic Spanish Tapas. Portions are large, order on the lesser side; ingredients are fresh; atmosphere is relaxed & locally rustic; & it is excellent value for money. We...
review_full: Nestled away & easily unnoticed, don't be fooled by Casa Toni's exterior aesthetic, this humble restaurant epitomises authentic Spanish Tapas.  Portions are large, order on the lesser side; ingredients are fresh; atmosphere is relaxed & locally rustic; & it is excellent value for money.  We particularly enjoyed the fried anchovies, potato with spicy sausage & egg, & grilled mushrooms.  Lovely service; waiter/cook spoke enough English.  Best advice; get here early, as there are a limited number of tables, but for a complete local experience; be seated at the bar. Bon Appetite!

title_review: Not the first to discover how excellent this is!!
review_preview: We had been recommended this pintxos bar by our son but our hotel said it was very difficult to get in as it was very popular, although they had tried to telephone without success.  In hope rather than expectation we got there at opening time...
review_full: We had been recommended this pintxos bar by our son but our hotel said it was very difficult to get in as it was very popular, although they had tried to telephone without success. In hope rather than expectation we got there at opening time (1 p.m. on a Sunday) and they squeezed us into a corner table. Despite probably being the worst table in the bar, we could not have cared, as the food, service and ambiance more than made up for it and we were just grateful to have been found any table. The food was exceptional and we had the wine recommended by our waiter, which was a perfect accompaniment to the food. We even had to ‘struggle’ with dessert and were very glad we did, as again these were superb. Our waiter looked after us excellently (and spoke good English – a bonus as our Spanish is non-existent) despite it being very busy. Next time we are in Madrid we will book well in advance…!

review_preview: This restaurant is one of my worldwide favorites. I had the pleasure to enjoy a meal there two times this year and both times I will remember for the rest of my life. Thanks to Mery Marte and her team! The restaurant is situated in...
review_full: This restaurant is one of my worldwide favorites. I had the pleasure to enjoy a meal there two times this year and both times I will remember for the rest of my life. Thanks to Mery Marte and her team! The restaurant is situated in a wonderful historic building at the corner of Plaza Espana. There is a set menu only, but they will ask, whether you have allergies or you do not like special kinds of food.  The food is fresh from the market, innovative, surprising, presented with fantasy and creativity and it tastes delicately like heaven! This time I enjoyed grilled tigerprawns and tiny mussels with special essential oils, a butter fish shot with white asparagus foam, a warm lobster salad with mango guacamole, a reduced soup from onions with a special “cheeseball”, baked turbot with seasonal baby vegetables, a confit suckling pig with shallots reduction, an edible hibiscus flower with foam from Pisco Sour, “Petals”, a fabulous rose flavoured ice cream with green apple sorbet, “Rocks”, chocolate rocks with mint and tonka bean ice cream and finally the “Blackboard” of Petits Fours. Wines are offered by the bottle only, very comprehensive wine list and a sommelier with good recommendations. Special thanks to my waiter Joao Miguel, who impressed with impeccable service, knowledge and humour and for the kind invitation to have a look inside the kitchen. The interiors are elegant and tasteful, sophisticated atmosphere. Reservations are essential. Spoil yourself and enjoy a wonderful meal there!

review_preview: We went to this restaurant after having seen the website and read the reviews on tripadvisor. Any reviewer that complained about the "pretentiousness" or "small quantities" or even "high price" obviously did no background check (all the information is easily attainable) and was therefore unprepared...
review_full: We went to this restaurant after having seen the website and read the reviews on tripadvisor. Any reviewer that complained about the "pretentiousness" or "small quantities" or even "high price" obviously did no background check (all the information is easily attainable) and was therefore unprepared and not in a position to criticise.  **** SPOILER ALERT !!!!! SPOILER ALERT !!!!! ***** (just in case you want the experience to also be a surprise, stop reading now. Go, eat, smell, taste, enjoy - you'll have an INCREDIBLE time) Still here? I understand: you're like me and want to be completely prepared. Well, I'm writing this review for you then, so here goes! We ordered the 11 course menu. 86 Euros, wine not included. The wine list was extensive and the sommelier was kind, patient and knowledgeable.  We ate: ..ok, I can't give away the first appetizer, because it's too much fun. Suffice to say that it's unexpected and light ;) - the second course was my personal favourite. What looked like a whole truffle on a bed of woodchips was, in fact, a pigeon...meatball. That tasted so good I can still remember it if I think hard enough. And the woodchips? Frozen foie gras, shaved so thin that it literally melted in your mouth. There was also what looked like a yellow flower, and a pea shoot. Which were a yellow flower and a pea shoot. The surprise was under the glass bowl that the course was served in, that was double an held in between the two layers a thick, brown smoke that smelled of forest. Yep. What happened during that course, which as I repeat was my favourite, was that thanks to the skill and passion of the chef (that unfortunately we did not meet) I was transported into a forest. I could go on, but let's move to the next dish. - seafood. Simple, but high quality, seafood: a prawn, a razor clam and two clams. No trick here. The twist however came in the shape of four tiny pipettes that contained four different aromatic oils, that had to be put on the four seafood items to give them a unique and personalised taste. I tried all of them before (I am too curious) and they were all very good. Ah, no cutlery was served with this course... only fingers allowed! - a raviolo. Well, we're Italian, so we frowned on this "raviolo" definition, and maybe because of this it was the least exciting of them all. A pea filling with shaved jamon topping and a reduced dewlap (pork cheek) sauce. Good, but not my favourite. Salty. - sardine. However strangely, the things that I remember most of this course were the origano flower (SO tasty! I am going to use flowers in all my dishes from now on) and the apple bites on top. The sardines were very salty and went extremely well with the celeriac cream. The roe was too little (quantity) to judge.  - lobster. Also not a favourite of the evening. Maybe because I've eaten lobster before and the mango guacamole wasn't overwhelmingly interesting. The colours were also a bit off, with the greenish-brown of the guacamole that wasn't a feast for the eyes, really. - turbot. It's a fish. A tasty, buttery fish that was served with a simple arbequina sauce and ... a garlic flower! SO tasty! (did I write that already?). This course was very good, original and interesting.  - Pigeon. The most beautiful course, this pigeon was served with a salad of shoots, nasturtium flowers and laid on a bed of soccarrat truffle rice. Soccarrat is the crunchy part of the paella rice, in this case made ad hoc for the dish. Very good, very beautiful. Loved it. - Dessert n1! A strange pinkish concoction made with a pisco sour foam on top of caramelised hibiscus flower and pistachio crumble. Strange, delicate, sour, sweet... A party in my mouth. - Dessert n2! The most creative of them all: the famous FishBowl! Nemo (the waiter said it was Nemo), that was a marshmallow sitting in a cloud of bubbles, was perched on an underwater "boulder" of yoghurt covered with green churro "algae" (crunchy, sweet, really good). Behind him rose a "coral" of white chocolate covered with raspberry powder and hidden under the boulder was a dark chocolate "mussel". This was a feast for the eyes, and for our imagination. - Dessert n3! The least interesting: chocolate rocks. Nothing much to add... tasted (the chef's going to kill m, but..) like Cadbury's Bubbly chocolate. Not exciting but still good. Maybe nothing should be served after the FishBowl. - the last dessert was a blackboard of passionfruit, churros and I can't really remember the last thing. Not bad as a sweet thing to end the dinner but as I said, maybe nothing should be served after the FishBowl.  Done! Now for the service: The waiter we had seemed a bit "off" at the beginning, not really smiling and acting all uptight. After the first surprise course however he starting warming up to us and was smiling and laughing by the end :) His English, as has been said, was not fluent but his effort was great and most things were easily understandable.  Every course was served on a unique and original plate - sometimes a stone, sometimes a glass bowl, other times an oddly shaped plate. Every dish was presented in such a way that all senses were stimulated and taken care of. Every moment was incredible, and I was very lucky to be able to share this amazing experience with my friends and family. This is not a dinner, or a lunch. It's an experience, in which the portions are small but many because of the generosity of the chef, that wants to share with his clients many different tastes and combinations.  Do not go if you want to fill up on comfort food. Do not go if you want to just eat.  Go if you want to have all your senses pampered and if, as everyone including myself has said several times, you want a completely amazing EXPERIENCE.  Happy eating! :D

Regarding the dishes, I was surprised by the Huevos rotos con pisto, I've never tried a different proposal of the dish, and they were outstanding.

They provided English menus. The tapas were all very good. I would highly recommend the Musaka as well as the croquetas. Salomillo was also great. The bar is very nice as well so it's a great place to have a drink. Our waiter Alejandro was very welcoming and made our lunch even better with his great service.

title_review: Rated #1 Restaurant In Madrid? I Can See Why.
review_preview: First off. My words can not  begin to describe the culinary "experience" that is Club Allard. I walked right by the non descript building that houses the most incredible dining experience of my life. I can't do this restaurant (culinary theater?) justice by trying to...
review_full: First off. My words can not begin to describe the culinary "experience" that is Club Allard. I walked right by the non descript building that houses the most incredible dining experience of my life. I can't do this restaurant (culinary theater?) justice by trying to describing the 3 hour production. Yes, it took that long for my meal to be completed! I repeat. I was entertained and fed for 3 hours! Like a great movie or play that you have seen and your friend hasn't and you don't want to spoil it for them.......I'm not going to spoil it for you. Just go and send me a message. It IS pricey but worth EVERY dollar.  The servers were incredible and very informative and Chef Diego Guerro's vision and flavorful explosions were nothing short of the best production I have ever witnessed. Please go, the atmosphere, ambiance and impeccable taste and decorum will astound you.

review_full: I went to Tapa Tapa Arenal today (november 7) and was the worst place I ever been in my life. Madrid is an awesome city with lots of good people and restaurants, but me and my mother was super mistreated by the maitre of that place for absolutely NO REASON. We tried to sit on a table and he roughly asked us to change the table with a mix of bad english speaking with unrecognizable spanish. Then he just (roughly again) throw the menu in our table and ignored us when we tried to ask for the dishes. In less than 5min we got up and left. And he ironically said "hasta luego" shaking his hands on a "bye bye" movement. I know we all have bad and good days but that was unacceptable for a restaurant like that. I'll never back again.

The front of house guy is just brilliant and the staff here are fabulous, yes it’s not cheap, but not four of us Parents with young adult children had 9 tapas 2 deserts 3 cokes, 3 wines and a bottle of white for less than €120.00. We will be back, La Latina is the place to eat and drink in Madrid, and we absolutely loved it. Would recommend going in around 9 to go on the post 10pm waiting list, then go and explore the any one of the roof top bars and cafes and come back later for a fabulous meal. Make sure you ask them to bring them in the order you want to eat them.

title_review: Superb food and service; venue congested and noisy
review_preview: Probably the best tapas we've had during our 3 weeks in Spain (taking in Barcelona, Malaga, Seville and now Madrid). Every one of our choices was delicious - the soft shell crab, the mussels, the volcano cake dessert, but the pick was the wild mushroom,...
review_full: Probably the best tapas we've had during our 3 weeks in Spain (taking in Barcelona, Malaga, Seville and now Madrid). Every one of our choices was delicious - the soft shell crab, the mussels, the volcano cake dessert, but the pick was the wild mushroom, black truffle and egg yolk ravioli which was astonishing. Service was helpful and friendly - our waiter had a great sense of humour and we enjoyed good banter throughout our visit. One word of warning. That picture of the restaurant area on the front page of the website for the venue was taken when the place was closed. Once it opens, the bar area gets very crowded and noisy and the standing guests are pressing up quite close to the tables. They also seem to have a weird system where the guy at the door controlling the numbers still sends people right to the other end of the bar to enquire about a table, only to be told there aren't any - so they have to squeeze past and then squeeze back. The waiters do an amazing job in such cramped conditions. I guess that means this is one of the places to be in Madrid at the moment, but don't go expecting a quiet, relaxed evening. Extroverts will love it, but introverts might feel a bit closed in. Still, I recommend this place for the food and service.

review_preview: There are no mad Queens to be seen (or at least not when we visited) but the food is to die for.Juana la Loca is a small restaurant located opposite the plaza de Puerta de Moros  with great atmosphere and an amazing menu. We...
review_full: There are no mad Queens to be seen (or at least not when we visited) but the food is to die for. Juana la Loca is a small restaurant located opposite the plaza de Puerta de Moros with great atmosphere and an amazing menu. We tried 4 of their dishes and all were sublime and highly recommended. In order of preference but just about equally good, do try the sea bass(tirafito de Corvina), ravioli de boletus, secreto iberico and the artichokes "laminadas". This is not a cheap restaurant but great value for money if you enjoy good food. The staff were super friendly, service is good. Definately a place we will visit again when we next visit Madrid.

title_review: Gourmet experience in the middle of La Latina
review_preview: On a hot August evening, we braved the crowds of the La Paloma festival in Madrid’s La Latina district to make our way to Juana La Loca. We knew it was rated as one of Madrid’s best restaurants and our concierge recommended reservations, an advice...
review_full: On a hot August evening, we braved the crowds of the La Paloma festival in Madrid’s La Latina district to make our way to Juana La Loca. We knew it was rated as one of Madrid’s best restaurants and our concierge recommended reservations, an advice we did not heed sadly. Once inside, the modern decor and the small dining room surprised us. The bar was the focal point of the restaurant and we were greeted by Phillipe. He was the bartender, sommelier, manager all rolled into one. He gave us a table despite no reservations and we were lucky as within a half hour, the place had filled up to more than capacity and folks were clamoring and waiting for a table. But I digress. It’s all about the food. Every single pintxos was excellent. Whether a seafood, meat or veggie dish it was exquisitely prepared with the flair of a Michelin chef. Memorable and notable dishes were the unusual peppers that were roasted, smoked salmon with curry and greens, spinach crepe, Iberian pork loin with sobrasada and gernika peppers were show stoppers. They had an impressive wine list and Phillipe guided us to one of the best wines we had ever had in Spain or anywhere- Ribera del duero.  But the icing on the cake was literally a cake with ice cream. The volcano with its gooey dulce de leche sauce oozing out was to die for. All in all, this was fine dining experience in a classy modern interior in the heart of the bustling city with great food, excellent service and ambience.  Disclaimer: I think the managers name was Phillipe. Can’t be sure.  See picture of “the volcano” below.

review_preview: It was sooo good we had to come back the next day. On both days we ordered the fried aubergines with honey and duck confit - excellent that some days later I’m still dreaming about it(lol)!!! We also had the truffles risotto with mushrooms -...
review_full: It was sooo good we had to come back the next day. On both days we ordered the fried aubergines with honey and duck confit - excellent that some days later I’m still dreaming about it(lol)!!! We also had the truffles risotto with mushrooms - exquisite. We also had soft shell crab in steamed bun and carrot ginger pie yogurt. Every dish here is made out of passion - everything has the right amount of taste. Too bad I can’t try their raw dishes like tuna tartar due to my current dietary restrictions - the next table to us can’t stop raving about it! Make sure to book table for dinner, for lunch without reservations, try to arrive before 2pm which is the lunch time for the locals, otherwise, you might have luck to get a free table. When I return to Madrid, will come back here for sure!

review_preview: We had high hopes for the #1 TA rated restaurant in Madrid, particularly after we had one of the best meals we had ever experienced the night before in Barcelona at Restaurant Montiel.  Unfortunately as much as we wanted it to be phenomenal, it was...
review_full: We had high hopes for the #1 TA rated restaurant in Madrid, particularly after we had one of the best meals we had ever experienced the night before in Barcelona at Restaurant Montiel. Unfortunately as much as we wanted it to be phenomenal, it was not. The service was extraordinary and the setting is very elegant. But the food just did not cut it on the evening of our visit. In an interesting start you are given the the three tasting menu selections on a potato based card that you can dip in a mayo sauce. Well it is different, but does it taste good? No not really! The second serving was a small biscuit with a 1/4 inch thick slab of butter. I ate it and wow it tasted like a slab of butter! Hmm if this is the haute cuisine then I guess I need to get use to eating slabs of butter or perhaps I just don't have a clue about haute cuisine!! I assume the chef experiments with each meal and perhaps sometimes you just miss the mark. Unfortunately we just found that one dish after another the flavors presented were not married but in fact clashed. This was apparent as we looked around the room and saw the puzzled look on many of the patrons faces the night of our visit. The desserts were interesting but in my opinion they were not great. Many people have very much enjoyed Club Allard so I will assume that it was an off night for the chef, but in our opinion Nemo was not found on the evening of our visit!!

review_full: We hadn’t book a table for a Saturday night on a recent 4 day visit to Madrid. The maitre’d said he would have a table in 40 minutes so we ventured out for an aperitif as the bar was extremely busy and noisy (great buzz). On returning 45 minutes later we only had to wait a couple of minutes for our table, which was at the back of the restaurant and a bit more tranquil. The waiter, from Bulgaria, was very helpful and offered us very good advice on choice and quantity. We chose the famous tortilla, suckling pig and a special mushroom dish. Great suggestions and all very, very tasty. The wine list was extensive and not too expensive. The waiter was attentive and good fun. Altogether a most successful meal especially as we hadn’t booked.

title_review: Fantabulous elaborate tapas and dining experience, truly not to be missed!
review_preview: Spain has incredible food (almost) wherever you go.  So it is very difficult to come across a place that is outstanding in every single way.  This to me is Juana la Loca.  From the minute we were received at the entrance to the last goodbye...
review_full: Spain has incredible food (almost) wherever you go. So it is very difficult to come across a place that is outstanding in every single way. This to me is Juana la Loca. From the minute we were received at the entrance to the last goodbye from our incredible master table host Diego... the experience was flawless. Juana la loca has truly made an art of taking the well known classics of Spanish tapas and regional dishes and turning them into quasi religious experiences ;-) From the wine list (very intelligent and well chosen selections including the Alvaro Palacios wines) to the offers on the menu Juana la loca truly allows you to choose fantastic culinary journeys. And this is still without talking about desserts which are out of this world. From the gingered Carrot cake to the overflowing 'dulce de leche' lava cake you are truly in for a treat. But I do have to say that at least half of the experience was crafted by Diego our table consultant hahahaha. A server beyond belief who not only showed his deep knowledge about the cuisine and ingredients on the menu but also provided fantastic recommendations, opinions, entertainment and truly allowed and gifted our table with so many good laughs. Viva Colombia!

title_review: Great atmosphere. Good vegetarian tapas. Excellent service.
review_preview: We chose this great little place as we wanted to eat tapas but being vegetarian needed to select the right place. A previous review on TA suggested that this place is good for vegetarians. It's a small place with a bar and was very busy...
review_full: We chose this great little place as we wanted to eat tapas but being vegetarian needed to select the right place. A previous review on TA suggested that this place is good for vegetarians.  It's a small place with a bar and was very busy with mainly Spanish clientele (a good sign in my book). Despite being busy we were greeted quickly and warmly by a waiter named Alex who then took care of us. His English was impeccable and he was talkative and very friendly. My children and I felt immediately at ease. He helped us pick out 5 vegetarian items (some contained eggs but we're OK with eggs). The food was hot and tasty and of good portion size. The bread was soft and fresh and I had 2 Sangrias which were very fruity. We heard the deserts were good and we ordered a homemade chocolate cake which Alex said his sister made. I don't know if he was pulling my leg but the cake was definitely home-made and delicious! Truly.  We left feeling very happy. The food was great with plenty of options for us. Service was excellent, thanks to Alex primarily. Ambience was great. All in all we had a thoroughly good meal and experience.  I can't express how much good service is important to a dining experience. Here it was great and made a good meal a great and enjoyable experience too. Well done Taberna el Sur!! Would most certainly eat here again. Recommend to vegetarians.

title_review: Delicious food, if you're lucky enough to get a table
review_preview: The food here is a mix of modern Spanish dishes and pintxos.  We ordered about 5 or 6 different ones and 1 dessert and it was all excellent.  Pricey, especially considering how affordable a lot of restaurants in La Latina are, but I guess that...
review_full: The food here is a mix of modern Spanish dishes and pintxos. We ordered about 5 or 6 different ones and 1 dessert and it was all excellent. Pricey, especially considering how affordable a lot of restaurants in La Latina are, but I guess that comes with "sophisticated" dishes. The two dishes that really stood out for us were the black truffle sea bass "tiradito" and the strigoli with truffle carbonara. The sea bass was incredible and melts in your melt. The truffle was interesting in the sauce, in a really good way. We were definitely scraping the sauce when all the fish was gone. The strigoli was also amazing and creamy, not too heavy if you're splitting the dish. The restaurant is extremely popular for people dining at tables and at the bar for pintxos. Tried to walk in around 10pm in June, not realizing it was a Friday and it was packed. Tried again a couple weeks later for dinner on a weekday just after opening. The restaurant was empty except one table and most table had reserved signs. I believe we got 1 of the 3 non-reserved tables and the wait staff still needed to ask the manager. We were lucky to sit and the non-reserved tables filled up shortly after us and reserved table not long into our meal. So definitely recommend coming at opening time or reserve your table. I'd say the service was good. Some of the staff may come off disrespectful to some but I think it's just them being quick with their interactions in an extremely packed and loud restaurant. They still managed to come around the tables fairly often, which isn't really expected in Spain. The manager also takes the time to go around the table to ask about your experience and explain some of the dishes. All in all, slightly overpriced and the ambience too busy for my taste but I would definitely come back to try other dishes.

review_preview: If you are looking for any info on the food, decoration, atmosphere or price from Juana la Loca, no need to read. I did not stay enough to say anything about it :-)I was just passing by, alone, on normal Saturday lunchtime and Madrid....
review_full: If you are looking for any info on the food, decoration, atmosphere or price from Juana la Loca, no need to read. I did not stay enough to say anything about it :-) I was just passing by, alone, on normal Saturday lunchtime and Madrid.  I look at Google Maps in my phone where I bookmark places I like or I wish to go. I had Juana la Loca bookmarked. I cannot remember if someone tipped it to me or if I just read it somewhere. I decided to go for it. Just before I get in, a group of three people entered the restaurant, so I had to stand by for some seconds. The restaurant had some people in the bar, gladly enjoying their meals, I could see an empty table that properly marked as reserved. It was 13:30 which is quite early lunchtime for Madrid standards. I had no rush, my program for today was to hit the streets and enjoy the beautiful early Madrid autumn. I asked for a table to one of the employees, and he politely told me that I should go a meet the manager who is in charge of arranging the seats. The manager, just came in from a room that I could not see. I asked that I was looking for a table and then i clarified it was just for me. He told me “I am sorry. But you have to wait 25m for a table or get a place in the bar”. I told him “that’s fine for me, I can squeeze myself on the bar but first I need to go to the toilet”. He answered back that I had to go to the same room where he came in from before. I walked in and I saw a room with 3/4 empty tables not marked as reserved. And the group that just came before me already accommodated. That moment I just realized the guy was greedily trying to put in the bar while not giving me a table that it was what I asked. Why “waste” a table for two with one guy that could eat at the bar? Rule number #1 in business and specially on services: empathy. I just felt like being another credit card and not as a person. You can have great food or not, amazing decor or be the most tide up place, but I don’t eat where I don’t feel welcomed. Maybe it was just a bad day or even a bad moment. I don’t know but I will not find out. I used the toilet an left, thank you for that.

review_preview: On the first day of this trip we stumbled upon the tavern and there was something I really liked about it. So we decided to go inside, even though it seemed packed. It was packed, after all it was Saturday night, so we had to...
review_full: On the first day of this trip we stumbled upon the tavern and there was something I really liked about it. So we decided to go inside, even though it seemed packed. It was packed, after all it was Saturday night, so we had to wait '15 till a table was available, which was fine. While waiting we sat at the bar and ordered some beers, to which the friendly bar-woman added a bowl of tasty olives. Our waiting time was very pleasant and gave us a chance to observe the interior, which gave me a warm feeling. It's walls were filled with Pedro Almodovar's movie posters, and there was a mixed crowd of young and older people. In general I got the impression that this was an honest, relaxed and fun place to be.  The staff was very friendly and relaxed, and our server, Alejandro, was a truly fun guy who spoke good english. What a surprise that he too had links to Charlotte, North Carolina. The world is a truly small place! In any case, despite the place being very busy, we felt like he was taking good care of us. Our food was very, very, tasty, I had the grilled baby squid with salad. Highly recommended. I also asked for a glass of white wine, and it was very good. Overhearing conversations with other customers I got the impression that they knew about wine and seemed like they have a good wine selection. The only downside was that we sat at the smallest table in the place, and since I'm a big guy and probably would have felt more comfortable in a bigger one. But since already I was in the mood for anything, and since we didn't have to wait longer for a bigger table, I was satisfied. Last, the prices were really great. I thought I'd spend at least 20 euro per person, what with the drinks etc. But it turned out to be almost half of that!  Overall a great place to have your dinner! Highly recommended.

review_preview: Having read a lot about Club Allard in the press, we recently finally came around to actually go and try the experience. It was truly memorable, mostly excellent, some parts outstanding, some parts 'only' very good. The treatment and service was perfectly friendly and helpful,...
review_full: Having read a lot about Club Allard in the press, we recently finally came around to actually go and try the experience. It was truly memorable, mostly excellent, some parts outstanding, some parts 'only' very good. The treatment and service was perfectly friendly and helpful, including car parking with the car efficiently brought back on time. If you are used to top class restaurants (we're not really) you might miss even more waiters ready to react at every move, we felt perfectly happy with what was provided. As you probably knew before reading this, having dinner at Club Allard or similar restaurants is nothing like a standard meal, instead you partake in a sort of organized trip through the culinary world of the specific chef. In this case part of the emphasis is on the peculiar presentation like the famous fake egg for dessert, part on the taste. The latter was unbelievably good for some dishes, while a few others remained just below maximal grades. Contrary to some other reviews, we were for example a bit less enamoured of the desserts, considering the starters the most rewarding part of the menu. We were offered a set of wines by the glass to go with the menu. These wines were all very nice, but only one I'd consider a true relevation. Given the quality of the food and the service, the price level was still relatively reasonable – keeping in mind with what you compare with.  Overall we enjoyed this dinner more than a much more expensive one in a 3-star restaurant many years ago and will definitely consider coming back for a special occasion.

review_preview: Getting there early (at 1:30 PM, yes early for Spanish standards) was definitely a good idea. The place is empty and silent; and one can really enjoy the email before dumb business people glued to their mobile phones enter your blissful realm.Let me start...
review_full: Getting there early (at 1:30 PM, yes early for Spanish standards) was definitely a good idea. The place is empty and silent; and one can really enjoy the email before dumb business people glued to their mobile phones enter your blissful realm. Let me start by stating that the meal was excellent. There was no dish that was disappointing. I decided to go for the big 17 course meal. Well worth it. Plan about 2.5h for the whole experience. People that complain about the experience should simply avoid haute cuisine because they are clueless. Sorry. The big highlight were the desserts. Absolutely out of this world. So good, that I had them 3 times (overall 7 desserts). Yes, I am a sucker when it comes to sweets. But let me tell you: the egg is absolutely stunning/surprising/delicious. True food porn. Shell is chocolate, white is panna cotta, yolk is mango coulis. Impossible to tell the difference to a real egg, until you try it. Yes, I will be back. Thank you, staff of El Club Allard, for (a) coping with my dietary requirements and (b) fixation on desserts. Truly a memorable experience. Some small gripes for a place of this category: No wine pairing, no wines by the glass, linens could be higher quality, sometimes the cutlery did not match the food (steak knife for fish?), my wine glass had a crack in the stem, door to toilet needs to be fixed.

The poche egg desert was an amazing creation- an exact egg replica but all of desert confections! Local wines were great- a cava from juve riserva 09 to start then a picarana, terca (white Rioja) a dominio bibei lalama and reds from alto moncayo and a sweet white from menade for desert. It may have been about 6a Denver time but this was worth it- almost up there with 11 Madison Park in NYC (which is better but this was great) and superior to Lynch's Menton in Boston. Worth it's 2 Michelin stars and likely 3.... Go there!!

There was no signage but we found a well dressed man tucked into the doorway. He eagerly led us into the spectacular dining room. The service was top notch and welcoming. The taste of food was excellent, but not the star of the show. The presentation is the real reason to come. Every dish was a work of art and amazing. Make sure you bring a good camera, you will want to take pictures.

title_review: An outstanding eating experience.... The BEST!
review_preview: After a fabulous day tasting exclusive wines at Vega-Sicilia in Ribero Del Duero we went to the outstanding, el club Allard in Madrid. There were three set menus on offer and we chose the middle set menu (13 courses!!) at 98 Euros a head.If...
review_full: After a fabulous day tasting exclusive wines at Vega-Sicilia in Ribero Del Duero we went to the outstanding, el club Allard in Madrid. There were three set menus on offer and we chose the middle set menu (13 courses!!) at 98 Euros a head. If I go into detail here it will spoil the excitement and surprise at some of the items and experiences that el club Allard has in store for their customer. Please take my word for it . This is an eating experience not to be missed. Chef Diego Guerrero is quite simply a genius! To whet your appetite one of the appetisers was a game truffle with foie and mushrooms. The egg with bread and pancetta served over a light potato cream sauce is incredible. Tuna from the north of Spain with tomato and almonds and chillie that was spicy but light on the tongue and suckling lamb shoulder with Tandori crumble yes Tandori crumble! The biggest surprise is with the two deserts...... Magnificent but I won't spoil your night. Go and experience it you will not be disappointed. Such value for money too.

The selection of tapas and raciones was very wide and so was the choice of drinks. We went with two tapas of "tortilla de papas" and "musaka", both potato based dishes which were absolutely great, we moved on to the house croquettes and a serving of "Solomillo al Sur". The latter was a great suprise. Our server Alex took great care of us, interacting positively from start to finish. The biggest highlight was the Solomillo, for sure. The croquettes were a bit of a letdown, but did nothing to diminish our experience.

review_preview: Taberna el Sur is wonderful. They have a great selection from salads to meats to desserts and drinks. You can order half portions or whole portions of many of the items. The food was so good here that we went for dinner one evening and...
review_full: Taberna el Sur is wonderful. They have a great selection from salads to meats to desserts and drinks. You can order half portions or whole portions of many of the items. The food was so good here that we went for dinner one evening and lunch the next day. I had a salad each time and tried some of the other entrees too. The sangria was also quite enjoyable. Everything we tried was delicious. My husband's favorite was the curry chicken. He continues to talk about it even now that we have returned home. It was his favorite dish of our entire vacation. We have also recommended this restaurant to family members to try when they were in Madrid, and they loved it just as much as we did. The service and atmosphere at Taberna el Sur makes it even better. Alex is very personable and makes a point to check in with the customers. I would definitely recommend this restaurant to anyone visiting Madrid. It is the best!

title_review: Amazing creativity and innovation, incredible flavors
review_preview: This restaurant started out as a private dining club and the premise is located in a very nice old building but understated with sign on the door. The service is very professional, without being overbearing. There are three menu options, differing only in the number...
review_full: This restaurant started out as a private dining club and the premise is located in a very nice old building but understated with sign on the door. The service is very professional, without being overbearing. There are three menu options, differing only in the number of appetizer courses. All the courses are innovative and artfully put together. I must admit that the first bite with the name card that tastes like hostia was not a success on taste or texture, but nevertheless a interesting start. The subsequent dishes never disappointed an eager diner. Among the dishes, the foie gras and baby lamb were simply outstanding. All other dishes were visually stunning with good taste to match, and disserts were amazing. The poached egg was one of the most spectacular dishes. The wine list is extensive and the prices are quite reasonable for the wines on the list. I wish there were a wine pairing available. It’s just too different to find a few wines that fit the large number of courses. Overall this now ranks among my top dining experiences and I recommend it highly. Can’t wait to go back to Madrid so that I can eat here again.

title_review: Possibly the best dessert courses ever...
review_preview: Tucked in a nondescript building with no signage, a security guard pointed us up the stairs to the restaurant. No ala carte options, just 3 tasting menus of various sizes - we opted for the middle option, Seduction. In retrospect, I probably could have gone...
review_full: Tucked in a nondescript building with no signage, a security guard pointed us up the stairs to the restaurant. No ala carte options, just 3 tasting menus of various sizes - we opted for the middle option, Seduction. In retrospect, I probably could have gone for the Revolution which had just one more starter. As other reviewers have commented on, the desserts were uniquely presented and just as importantly tasted amazing. There's a great attention to detail on getting the temperature of the food just right. Sounds like a strange concept, but the mouth feel of most/all entrees was exquisite. Should have done a wine pairing but just opted for a starter and dessert wine. BTW, this outing was the least expensive of our gastronomic Vuelta de España.

Sangia looked huge, but far too much ice to be honest. Good patatas bravas and tortilla.

review_preview: I had dinner with my colleague. We were appealed by the very good location and photos on the menu. Unfortunately, the dishes turned out to be quite different from the pictures: Bellota slices were too thick, beef was burnt, and patatas bravas were hard. We...
review_full: I had dinner with my colleague. We were appealed by the very good location and photos on the menu. Unfortunately, the dishes turned out to be quite different from the pictures: Bellota slices were too thick, beef was burnt, and patatas bravas were hard. We sent back the beef, which was hard as a shoe sole and tasted like dirt. When it came back it was literally raw... Service was extremely poor: we had to ask 5 times for the wifi code, nobody was willing to give it to us. When time came to pay, we asked 3 times for the bill and had to wait 45 minutes to receive it. It had 2 mistakes on it, adding up to more than 10 euros so make sure you double check your bill. We found they have their way to overcharge you: we ordered some bread with tomato and olive oil, since there was 2 of us, they automatically charged us 2 portions (which means 6 slices of bread, of course we left half of it) and when we questioned the bill they told us we should have precised we wanted only one serving... This place is a tourist trap. Stay away.

title_review: a tapas place for tourits occasionally trying this Spanish snacks
review_preview: It is called Tapa Tapa Montera.This venue is for tapas, as well as for eating. It locates at a major Madrid commercial district, the gran via, opposite metro station Gallao and magnificent Senator gran via hotel. A handsomely bearded waiter named Josu spoke very good...
review_full: It is called Tapa Tapa Montera.This venue is for tapas, as well as for eating. It locates at a major Madrid commercial district, the gran via, opposite metro station Gallao and magnificent Senator gran via hotel. A handsomely bearded waiter named Josu spoke very good English and thus gave us some quite needed help. To be fair, people there waiting tables used English quite often, so tourists can feel relieved in ordering dishes they want and portions they could consume, rather than wasting. Josu correctly explained the drink we saw many other people drinking, the rose-colored sangria. We had tried asking waiters at other places since we got to Madrid, but often got confused and gave up. This time we tasted it, and it is quite pleasant, for having tapas or just lessening thurst under the sun. The venue offers a variety of tapas choices, mostly delicious, good for tourists who did not intend to venture into places like San Miguel to taste local tapas, and the location is so convenient that you can hardly miss it while joining crowds around this central Madrid commercial district. Sent from my MIPHONE

For great authentic Spanish food go to El Sur. You won’t be disappointed.

title_review: Some of the most amazing tapas we've had!
review_preview: So there we were... on our way to Casa Patas for some authentic Flamenco and a colleague of mine suggested this place.  We walked in and it was going to be a loooooong wait for a table.  So we stood at the bar in front...
review_full: So there we were... on our way to Casa Patas for some authentic Flamenco and a colleague of mine suggested this place. We walked in and it was going to be a loooooong wait for a table. So we stood at the bar in front of all those good looking tapas in the case. And they were beautiful. And that's where we stayed and ate some of the most delicious tapas we've ever had.. The guys behind the bar serving us were so funny and fun. They were having a blast serving so many people packed at the bar. There wasn't one tapas we didn't like and we tried about 7 of them. And it was reasonable! In the end it made for a really memorable dinner that one week later we're still talking about.

review_preview: Okay, let me tell you that I have been working in hospitality for over 12 years and food is my passion.I tried so many restaurants in my life but without any doubt I can tell you that Juana la Loca was the best one!...
review_full: Okay, let me tell you that I have been working in hospitality for over 12 years and food is my passion. I tried so many restaurants in my life but without any doubt I can tell you that Juana la Loca was the best one! The place is small and cozy, Friendly and prepared staff, unique food. It's been few months since we were there but if I close my eyes I can still taste the fat and the tenderness of the foie gras, perfectly cooked. I remember the baked eel with ham and the fish with an amazing foam and truffle. I should have rated them months ago and give you a more detailed description but I can confirm I would go back to Madrid only for this place. We liked it so much that we went back the day after for lunch and we took their potatoes and onions traditional dish as take away for our return trip. If I could open my own restaurant one day, Juana la loca would be the place I will be inspired from. Fine dining modern tapas using tradition and passion. Well done!

title_review: elegant surroundings, excellent service, (mostly) successful dishes
review_preview: It is really a pleasure to sit in the elegant dining room of Club Allard and to enjoy the solicitous and friendly service of the highly professional staff.  First the most impressive part of our dinner:  the excellent sommelier guided us through the lengthy meal...
review_full: It is really a pleasure to sit in the elegant dining room of Club Allard and to enjoy the solicitous and friendly service of the highly professional staff. First the most impressive part of our dinner: the excellent sommelier guided us through the lengthy meal with five wine selections (bottles) of his choice - all matching the food superbly and providing most pleasurable drinking experiences. We were prepared to pay dearly for this fine selection and were pleasantly surprised that our expert guide had selected bottles averaging about 33 Euros! A steal! I was unable to order wine from the grotesquely overpriced wine lists of New York and Philadelphia restaurants for months. To the food: Club Allard's menu has many playful ideas, ranging from lovely trompe d'oeil dishes to enticing "molecular" bites, interspersed, however, with some less exciting ideas. The menu-eating conceit should yield a more intense opening gustatory experience, as other reviews confirm, instead of providing, in my case, a slightly sacrilegious feeling of breaking a large host. The same lack of scintillation afflicted a couple more dishes in the long parade of the "Revolution" menu, however, most selections were truly outstanding in quality and preparation and were a delightful treat together with the wines. It must be said that for a two-star Michelin restaurant with all the elegant trappings and generous staffing, the prices of the menus are very reasonable, making the quality/price ratio an excellent one. I intend to return for the special treat of dining at Club Allard when back in Madrid.

review_full: El Club Allard is gourmet dinning at its very best. The tasting menu was a veritable parade of delicacies, most excellent and others even better than that.  My preference not to eat fish or crustaceans was informed by me at the restaurant, when my order was taken, not previously, yet my preference was fully accommodated in what I was served, and at the end of our meal I was given a printed menu reflecting exactly what I had been served, not what was served to everybody else who ordered the same tasting menu but did not have the same preference as I. Very impressive.  Service was very good, but some minor details can be improved, such as offering more wine and / or water when my cup was empty. Twice I had to ask for more because it was not offered to me.  In summary I fully recommend El Club Allard to those who want and appreciate a truly sophisticated gourmet dinning experience.
