review_preview: Great place. The reviews are right. I went into El Sur on my own after reading the reviews and visiting the American hairdresser at No 8. If you need a hairdresser in Madrid he is your guy. He is just lovely. As soon as I...
review_full: Great place. The reviews are right. I went into El Sur on my own after reading the reviews and visiting the American hairdresser at No 8. If you need a hairdresser in Madrid he is your guy. He is just lovely.  As soon as I went into El Sur Alex greeted me straight away and seated me at a table. Asked was I having drinks or drinks and dinner. He presented me with an English menu. At home I normally let the people who know order for me and I did the same here. I was delighted with the beef which he recommended. He said to only order a half portion and the prawns. If I wanted more it was not going to be a problem. He was right it was enough.  I asked him to recommend a White Wine which he did and it was lovely. Then I had the cheesecake! Absolutely Devine.  Jasmine came with bread and chatted to me for a while which I thought was really nice as I was having dinner alone. She offered more bread and gave me recommendations of where to go in the city.  I was tempted to go back again tonight but decided to wait until I'm back in Madrid later in the year.  A great experience! It does not look like a job for Alex and Jasmine they look and act so happy that I thought they actually owned the place but they don't! I hope their boss appreciates them. I certainly did.  Thank you for a great evening.

review_preview: The restaurant location is in a corner historic building were no signs are allowed. Inside, the restaurant's decor and lighting are just perfect. There are three prix fixe dinner options printed on edible paper. After you order, a nice creamy peanut sauce is presented so...
review_full: The restaurant location is in a corner historic building were no signs are allowed. Inside, the restaurant's decor and lighting are just perfect. There are three prix fixe dinner options printed on edible paper. After you order, a nice creamy peanut sauce is presented so you can eat your menu. At that point you now you are in for a treat. We chose the middle prix fixe option which comprises of twelve dishes including appetizers and desserts. My favorites were the fried soft shell crabs, three small crabs that tasted amazing and were beautifully presented; another favorite was the egg-inside-pastry with pancetta; the lubina fish and lamb dishes were perfectly cooked. The menu is inventive and the waiter did a great job presenting and explaining each dish. At the end, Meri Marte, the Dominican-born chef that took over this restaurant in 2013, came to our table. A very nice touch to cap a memorable night. Assume €150 pp.

review_preview: Faultless!  I don't want to say too much and spoil the surprise for others but this was one of the most amazing meals I've had.  I enjoyed every morsel and loved the imaginative and playful presentation. We had the shortest menu as it was lunchtime...
review_full: Faultless! I don't want to say too much and spoil the surprise for others but this was one of the most amazing meals I've had. I enjoyed every morsel and loved the imaginative and playful presentation.  We had the shortest menu as it was lunchtime - the Rendevouz includes 2 appetisers, 7 courses and the most beautifully served petit fours I have ever had. The courses are dainty but we didn't leave feeling hungry. The meal took around 2 1/2 hours and was a wonderful experience overall. An additional thing which impressed me was that although they kept topping us up with wine, they weren't heavy handed and our aperitif and bottle of wine lasted the meal. Plenty other places would have pushed to sell us the second bottle. The whole thing was a joy and next visit to Madrid, the first thing I will do is book a table, ideally for dinner next time.

title_review: Can it get any better anywhere?
review_preview: You know you are in for a superlative dining experience with the welcome you receive on entering this restaurant and any lingering doubts about the event to unfold are dispelled when your waitor using tweezers inserts your menu on the setting on the table which...
review_full: You know you are in for a superlative dining experience with the welcome you receive on entering this restaurant and any lingering doubts about the event to unfold are dispelled when your waitor using tweezers inserts your menu on the setting on the table which you are shortly after encouraged to then eat! Don't make the mistake that this is some sort of left field experimental dining but rather an extraordinary high end journey with each dish continuing to leave you gobsmacked. It just gets better and better with an extraordinary desert (s) finale. Too much detail will ruin the experience for you although it is suffice to say my wife and I left pondering whether we had ever eaten a better meal ( and we have had the privilege at eating at more than six 3 Michellin star and a dozen or so other starred restaurants). This restaurant needs to be on the the "must do" list in Madrid and certainly deserving of a third star. On cost, it is not cheap nor ridiculous and for me one of the most pleasing aspects were the varied pricing on the wine list from 25 euros and upwards. A refreshing change from those establishments who seem to want to compete with eath other on having the most complex and unaffordable lists! If I had one criticism it would be that although the service met and exceeded every other expectation, I was surprised the table napkins were neither replaced nor re folded at any point including when my wife and I left the table together for the bathroom. Finally don't make the mistake of arriving too early. The restaurant opens at 9.00 pm and we arrived at 9.15pm and were the first with other diners continuing to arrive until around 11.00pm. The meal for us and again we were the first to leave finished just after midnight.

review_preview: Enjoyed our experience at this restaurant on 14th November. Our waiters looked after us superbly from start to finish. Best gin and tonic I ever had. We booked it well in advance as my wife has coeliac disease and cannot eat wheat, barley or oat...
review_full: Enjoyed our experience at this restaurant on 14th November. Our waiters looked after us superbly from start to finish. Best gin and tonic I ever had. We booked it well in advance as my wife has coeliac disease and cannot eat wheat, barley or oat gluten. When we arrived they were completely ready for us making 3 types of gluten free bread as well as everything else gluten free. Most restaurants would try to simplify this kind of meal so that it was easy for them but not the Club Allard. The attention to detail on every course was excellent. We had the Seduction menu. As expected in such a style of menu there were some parts that were not something we would have chosen again but this in no way detracted from the experience or quality. Our bill was around 300 euro and it was worth every bit. Congratulations to your team in both the kitchen and front of house. We really enjoyed the evening and the effort to perform as highly for a coeliac person as everyone else in the restaurant was the best we have experienced. Our main waiter made our time special. Thank you to everyone.

Portion sizes were really good, so as I was dining solo, I didn't want to order a lot. I started with their cold tomato soup (like a gazpacho), then ordered the grilled Octopus (pulpo) which was fantastic. Again, large portions, and a subtly grilled flavour. The pulpo was on a separate menu for their specials, so it may/may not available all the time. My meal was finished with a complimentary mocha liqueur shot from the bartender. I didn't nor order any drinks from the bar, but have a wide selection of cocktails, and beer.  I would definitely return when I come back to Madrid.

title_review: The best fusion tapas bar in Madrid
review_preview: You must be crazy to miss "Juana La Loca". It's not in city center of Madrid but the food makes all the walk down Cava Baja-Alta worthwhile. The ambience is trendy pintxos bar with purple walls and it is popular with young professionals (they do...
review_full: You must be crazy to miss "Juana La Loca". It's not in city center of Madrid but the food makes all the walk down Cava Baja-Alta worthwhile. The ambience is trendy pintxos bar with purple walls and it is popular with young professionals (they do have a screen tv for football matches). However small it is (all famous Madrilenos restaurants are small..) it makes up for the food which is excellent creative fusion Spanish pintxos at best. Try the beef stew, the crab hamburger and desserts.. The service also is one of the best in town. I live here and I can tell you I have never seen any other restaurant with waiters who know how to calm down hungry clients waiting for tables like in this one.  So if you are going for dinner, do call to reserve a table even if it's a two person table. This place is packed most nights than not.

Be prepared to wait for a table, but you will be seated at the earliest opportunity and will be given an idea of how long you will have to wait. I wish Juana la Loca was on my doorstep, I would live there!

review_preview: Well we were in Madrid in May for the Mutua Madrid Open.  We decided to skip the tennis one evening and take dinner at El Club Allard. I am so glad we did.The restaurant is in an unassuming building and not in what I...
review_full: Well we were in Madrid in May for the Mutua Madrid Open. We decided to skip the tennis one evening and take dinner at El Club Allard. I am so glad we did. The restaurant is in an unassuming building and not in what I think of as the center. However, there was a doorman who ushered us in. Upon entry, we were in this spacious, elegant restaurant full of elegant looking people. Service was corrrect and prompt. We were presented with their famous menu, which is edible and made of some type of edible paper.  The wine list was nice and reasonably priced, as was the food. Really compared to Paris or New York this place is a bargain. Fine food. Interesting presentations. Some dishes were really standouts. Fine service. Elegant atmosphere. We were very pleased. Our only disappointment was to learn that the chef had changed and the original chef has left to open his own establishment.  Highly recommended. May 2014

review_preview: I went there for a lunch with a couple of friends. We ordered Menu rendezvous (86 euros) which consists of Txangurro de cáscara bland (soft chell crab), 2 snacks (game truffle with foie and mushrooms, Pea's ravioli with iberique dewlap), 2 starters (cold cherry soup...
review_full: I went there for a lunch with a couple of friends. We ordered Menu rendezvous (86 euros) which consists of Txangurro de cáscara bland (soft chell crab), 2 snacks (game truffle with foie and mushrooms, Pea's ravioli with iberique dewlap), 2 starters (cold cherry soup with herring caviar, egg with bread served over a light potato cream sauce), 1 fish dish (skrey with rhubarb chutney and spring onion), 1 meat dish (confit suckling pig with echelon onion compote), 1 dessert appetizer (hibicus flower with pisco sour), 2 desserts (the fishbowl, chocolate rocks) then we had a coffee and petit fours which is called the black board.  I, personally, think it was a great meal but not all of the dishes have wowed me. Only the game truffle, the egg and the fishbowl (which are mainly white chocolate mousse) are really impressive. The rest, however, are great, well-cooked and interesting but the taste reached the michelin level but not wow.  The blackboard which are mash mellows, jelly and crackers with ginger flavours are not that good for my taste. The chocolate rocks (chocolate with mint dessert) has too strong chocolate flavour. However, the good point of the desserts here is that they are not TOO sweet nor a sugar bomb. The service was correct and proper. The waiters spoke good english and kindly explained us everything. The drinks were't included and since two of us don't drink, we decided to go for water. (5.5 euros/bottle).  Overall it was great meal with great deal. The decoration was interesting but the taste are good even though not a wow. (Maybe I expected too much after seeing it as number 1 of trip advisor in Madrid).

review_full: This is a lovely tapas bar in La Latina that serves both traditional and also more experimental tapas, pintxos and raciones. The tortilla made with caramelised onions is renowned and very good, but there are more inventive things on offer here - anguilas con huevo for instance. It's slightly pricier than other places in Madrid an, like the rest of the area it gets busy at weekends and has become quite touristy, but it's still worth a visit.

review_preview: I went with 4 friends this past Friday and we arrived around 10:00-- prime time for a weekend dinner. It was very crowded, but nothing I wouldn't expect. They had a decent variety of wines by the glass, and a range of prices. Being American,...
review_full: I went with 4 friends this past Friday and we arrived around 10:00-- prime time for a weekend dinner. It was very crowded, but nothing I wouldn't expect. They had a decent variety of wines by the glass, and a range of prices. Being American, they were quite a good price for me-- although higher than what I pay elsewhere in Spain. We waited about a half an hour at the bar and were shown graciously to our table. It was comfortable and romantic. We each ordered the famous tortilla and it didn't disappoint. It was the best I've tried. We shared the huevos rotos (delicious-- eggs cooked perfectly and perfectly crisp skinny french fries) risotto de trufa (great flavor although the risotto wasn't quite perfectly cooked) and a fish and goat cheese "dip" type plate that didn't quite make the mark for me. We spent 20 euro per person including a few glasses of wine each and a tip for the waiter (not always given in Spain). It seemed a bit pricy, but I really enjoyed everything about it. Next time I want to try more variety-- their menu was great.

The wine menu was huge but we had great help picking out cava, white wine and dessert wine. We got to pick between 3 food menus, the difference being the number of courses. We chose the middle one costing 98 euros pp as I see most of the people on TA also picked. We got 12 different courses traveling through all the areas of vegetables and meat that you can imagine, and they all both looked and tasted amazing. Luckily the portions were small so that I could eat all of them, though I was pretty full when I went home. We paid a total of 300 euros for two people with wine (2 glasses of cava, 2 dessert wine, 1 bottle white wine, 2 bottles water). It was definitely worth it.

It was good although probably not “world famous “ as the menu proclaims. My wife and daughter ordered the Grilled Duck foie grass which they are still raving about 4 hours later. We had the black truffled sea bass which was sashimi style and very good. The truffled risotto was very filling (very truffley)and then we finished off the dinner with Cochinillo lechal (suckling pig because hey we’re in Spain and you have to have suckling pig when you’re in Spain). Definitely the best suckling pig I’ve ever had. The skin was crispy and the pork was so tender! Staff was so friendly and helpful. Highly recommend. You won’t regret it.

review_preview: First time in Madrid, and have tried a handful of top price-fixe restaurants in U.S. and San Sebastian, and El Club Allard is hands down the top (or one of the top) dining experience I've had. The reasons I rate the dinner so highly are:...
review_full: First time in Madrid, and have tried a handful of top price-fixe restaurants in U.S. and San Sebastian, and El Club Allard is hands down the top (or one of the top) dining experience I've had. The reasons I rate the dinner so highly are: 1) Exceptional level of food for each course - Even at some of the best comparable restaurants, there will always be 1-2 courses that fall short. At El Club Allard every single course was fantastic. 2) Service - Great flow of food in terms of timing and staff, great atmosphere as well. No negatives really, the wine pairings were good, I've probably had a few better in terms of my own personal wine preferences, but that is really subjective as I tend to prefer red wines and because this was a seafood heavy meal most wines were white. But they were all good.

title_review: A fine dining experience to remember
review_preview: We chose this restaurant out of many in Madrid because it offered a choice of three tasting menus. The restaurant is in a lovely old building and you have to know it is there because there is no signage, but there is a doorman to...
review_full: We chose this restaurant out of many in Madrid because it offered a choice of three tasting menus. The restaurant is in a lovely old building and you have to know it is there because there is no signage, but there is a doorman to ensure you are a bona fide customer. Inside there is old world elegance. Large well spaced tables with white linen clothes. The staff are all very helpful and attentive. We went for the Seduction menu at 98 euros pp totalling 11 courses. 3 canapés, 3 starters, 2 mains, 1 dessert appetiser and 2 desserts. We also opted for the matched wines and the sommelier was more than willing to explain his choices and engage in discussion after the course. His choices by an large were very good, only one was over powered by the richness of the food. The portions are thankfully tiny but even so we were very full at the end. There was quite a lot of fish features and the courses were full of creative artistry. One starter was a pigeon fois gras made to look like a truffle with a mushroom crumb for soil, one of the desserts looked like a hens egg laying straw. The straw was coconut strands, the egg shell was pigmented white chocolate, the egg white was coconut panacotta and the egg yolk mango cream and broken in the dish looked exactly like a soft boiled egg. The artistry at every course was outstanding but then so was the quality of the textures and flavours, matched perfectly with fine wines. A 2 Michelin star restaurant is always going to be expensive, but I consider the experience good value at less than 300 euros for two. The whole event was a memorable end to our holiday, a truly outstanding restaurant.

The free round of cream liquors and cheesecake we received sealed the deal as everyone agreed this was the meal of the holiday.

review_full: My wife and I were looking for local flair, close to our hotel but not right in tourist trap area. A little research and trusting our instincts led us here. What an amazing place. The food is so fresh, the staff so welcoming, and drinks were spot on. Price wise, this was outstanding value, along with that the portions are quite filling. We jumped in both feet and had the patatas bravas ( and yes the sauce has a kick to it! perfect), had pork medallions and the third dish was the special of goat cheese stuff beef filet....every dish was full of flavor and I would each one again...Jose took care of us and he did a masterful job, well done sir!!! Sat next to two Swedish gentleman who had just finished part of the Camino and my wife shared stories with them. This should be on your radar. This is not fancy, a little crowded and certainly not snooty, just plain ol' great food, local tavern with real people serving/cooking. A+++++

Don't miss the pacharan, my favourite Spanish after dinner liquor.

review_preview: You can gather from all the previous reviews that this is a remarkable dining experience, which it is. The presentation and flavours of all the courses are a sensory delight. I would defy anyone not be overwhelmingly impressed by the signature ‘egg’ dessert, it’s truly...
review_full: You can gather from all the previous reviews that this is a remarkable dining experience, which it is. The presentation and flavours of all the courses are a sensory delight. I would defy anyone not be overwhelmingly impressed by the signature ‘egg’ dessert, it’s truly a culinary masterpiece.  The only reason I cannot give it the full 5 stars is based on the atmosphere and overall welcome. Perhaps some of the explanations of each course were just lost in translation and I felt as if we were doing the venue a favour by allowing us to eat there.   Guests appear to eat in silence; its atmosphere more akin to a monastery at mealtime. The staff, though clearly very professional and thorough, serve as if they are working in a morgue rather than a two Michelin-starred restaurant! They appear wooden, clinical and not at all relaxed. It’s also unusual for this style of gastronomic extravaganza not to offer any paired wines with each course which is somewhat disappointing.  I don’t think I have ever been to a similarly highly regarded establishment where you have to wait until exactly the required opening time before you are allowed in, nor is there an area in which to enjoy an aperitif or after dinner coffee or tea, the choices of which by the way are equally as diverse as the food. My advice is if you have the opportunity to eat here then do so, it really is an extravagant culinary experience and is not number one in Madrid without good reason, however expect a tepid welcome and dreary atmosphere that way the food will be the focus of your attention which is probably the objective anyway.

title_review: You don’t want to miss this tapas bar
review_preview: Without hesitations Go Go Go! You really don’t want to miss this tapas bar! If you didn’t reserve a table well in advance get ready to join line and wait about 40 minutes at least, depending on how lucky you are. But rest assured this...
review_full: Without hesitations Go Go Go! You really don’t want to miss this tapas bar! If you didn’t reserve a table well in advance get ready to join line and wait about 40 minutes at least, depending on how lucky you are. But rest assured this is probably one of the best tapas bars in Madrid. The truffled risotto with wild mushrooms is delicious, the grilled duck foie gras is a delicacy, the duck ham is unique and the Spanish omelette is simply the best that you will find in Madrid. If you have the chance to chat with Felipe, the chief waiter, you will get to know the place even better.

title_review: Creative fusion cuisine that takes advantage of what Spain has to offer
review_preview: I was in Spain for vacation last month and found myself in Madrid wondering where to go for dinner. A local friend asked one of his friend for fine dining recommendation and he suggested El Club Allard. I checked on TripAdvisor and it was #1...
review_full: I was in Spain for vacation last month and found myself in Madrid wondering where to go for dinner. A local friend asked one of his friend for fine dining recommendation and he suggested El Club Allard. I checked on TripAdvisor and it was #1 in Madrid, so I decided to give it a try. I was happy to get a table for myself when calling 2 days prior to my visit. The service was great and the food was really delicious. I asked the sommelier to help me with 3-4 glasses of wine and he did an amazing job pairing wine with my food. All Spanish wine and perfect with the food.  They offer three different menu and I went with the one with most courses. Food was more than plenty. Stunning presentation and playful interpretation of Spanish fine dining.  The chef came out to greet us towards the end of the meal. Really nice girl and extremely humble.  I hope to return again next time when I am in Madrid. Highly recommended!

review_full: I tried to book online but it said there was no availability, so I phoned and they DID have a table for the date and time that I wanted! We arrived at 8.55pm for a table at 9pm and were told (quite rudely) that they didn't open until 9pm, and the door closed in our faces..... If it had been any other reservation I would have not returned and eaten elsewhere.....  There is no bar for aperitifs so you are taken straight to the table. I can't add anything about the food - it's sublime and out of this world - a definite must! We had the middle menu (seduction) which was amazing. On the website it says that if you have children under 8 you must have a private dining room, however a couple arrived with a baby in a buggy and the baby cried and cried. Distressing for diners (who may have saved long and hard for this once in a lifetime experience) and for the staff (who seemed embarrassed) and for the parents who were then walking about with the buggy to get the baby to sleep. There is a rule for not arriving before 9pm but not for a crying baby??

review_full: From the unassuming location within a grand building, to the tasteful classically styled dining room, to the sophisticated Madrileño crowd, you feel outclassed here. And then the incredibly friendly service starts, and they tell you to eat your menu, and then the dishes comes out. And you realize you this is not a stuffy old restaurant - this is a place at the vanguard of exciting cuisine. We had the "seduction" menu, and I have to say that they absolutely did just that. Our favorite was the "fishbowl" complete with "sea weed", "rocks" and of course bubbles. (Our waiter to my vegetarian wife: "Now miss you're going to have to do something you've never done - you're going to eat a fish" (as it turns out a cute gummy construction)). There are many different ways to eat in Madrid. El Club Allard delivers an experience unlikely to be replicated elsewhere.

title_review: Best dinner I've had in Madrid
review_preview: First things first: it's a very expensive place. But, if you can splurge once, it's totally worth it. You have three menus to choose from, but I think the only difference is the number of dishes: more expensive give you more food. Everyone in the...
review_full: First things first: it's a very expensive place. But, if you can splurge once, it's totally worth it. You have three menus to choose from, but I think the only difference is the number of dishes: more expensive give you more food. Everyone in the table has to order the same menu. The food was without a doubt the best I've had in Madrid, and I don't think the amount will leave anyone hungry, although I'm known for not eating a lot. I think it took more than two hours for the whole dinner, as they bring the dishes one by one to the table. It's been a while, so I can't remember most of the dishes, but everything was very original and delicious. They spoke English and Spanish. The service was top notch, which you'd expect for the price anyway. Will deifnitely go again if I have the chance.

title_review: Hot spot in Madrid with delicious food in La Latina
review_preview: Im so glad my cousin who lived in Madrid took me to Juana La Loca in the La Latina neighborhood. La Latina is packed with bars and restaurants, one of the most popular of which is Juana La Loca.It is a cute neighborhood gem....
review_full: Im so glad my cousin who lived in Madrid took me to Juana La Loca in the La Latina neighborhood. La Latina is packed with bars and restaurants, one of the most popular of which is Juana La Loca. It is a cute neighborhood gem. We went in almost 11pm and they were still packed. They call themselves a pintxo bar but the food goes above and beyond the conventional pintxo. We were seated right away despite not having a reservation. Just had to try their tortilla de patata. We ordered pintxos dishes were all bold and tasty in their own way, they were all still light enough to pair well with wine. Try their famous dish the tortilla de patatas: a buttery, melt-in-the-mouth tortilla, finished with a crispy outer layer and served on top of a slice of bread. The huevos rotos also delicious, either to share or as a ración for yourself: crispy, chewy, buttery fries topped with melting fried egg, small salty strips of jamón, salted pimientos de padrón and a shake of paprika, all served on a long plate. It’s a little pricey to dine here but a nice treat when visiting Madrid! It is CASH only. It’s a small wine bar/restaurant and fills up quickly in the evenings. Fun place for a small, dark, cosy and lively, Juana La Loca is perfect for place for a taste of Madrid! Fives stars for overall dining experience!

Our waiter 'Douglas' was exceptionally nice and we gave him our permission to bring us any of his recommended dishes. We were lucky! He.made a splendid job and each plate was better than the other. The Tortilla turned out to be the most recognized dish of this place so it's a must. Prices are low so the experience is even better at the end. Enjoy !

We had the jambon to start and paella mixta and prawns to follow. Both were outstanding. Dessert not so great, but good. Delicious coffee, two glasses of wine, one beer and a bottle of sparkling water. The bill a staggeringly good value €44. Worth a detour.

review_preview: Ok, so I rarely write reviews, but after an excellent family meal out at Taberna el Sur this evening, I thought it only right to share our experience. 6 of us went out, including an 11 year old, three teenagers, my wife and I. We...
review_full: Ok, so I rarely write reviews, but after an excellent family meal out at Taberna el Sur this evening, I thought it only right to share our experience. 6 of us went out, including an 11 year old, three teenagers, my wife and I. We arrived to a back street restaurant / bar that looked uninviting from the outside, but once inside there was a nice lively and friendly atmosphere. We are used to ordering in a typically British way, ie starters then main. This is not really the Spanish way, and after getting a bit confused about what best to order, our very friendly host Lucas offered to bring us a selection of dishes. Great decision as we very quickly had many delicious dishes to try. My daughter commented that the garlic prawns were the best she'd ever tasted and our fussy 11 year old was soon tucking into various new dishes. Firm favourites were the garlic prawns, salmon salad, moussaka and gazpacho. All the staff were extra friendly and at 100 euros for 6 including drinks, this was definitely our best meal in Madrid so far - highly recommended.

title_review: Fantastic restaurant - one of the best meals in Madrid
review_preview: We went to Taberna el Sur after reading some of the great reviews on Trip Advisor. When we arrived (a Thursday night) the relatively small restaurant was already full so we sat at the bar for a drink whilst we waited for a table to...
review_full: We went to Taberna el Sur after reading some of the great reviews on Trip Advisor. When we arrived (a Thursday night) the relatively small restaurant was already full so we sat at the bar for a drink whilst we waited for a table to become free. When we did get a table, the service was extremely prompt with the food arriving in good time. And the food - wow! Highlights were the croquettes, steak dish and the pork in a red wine jus. To be honest, all the food was fantastic. But, coupled with this the staff at Taberna el Sur were just brilliant. Alex and Edison did everything they could to make sure we had a brilliant evening. We had some thoroughly good meals whilst in Madrid but I have to say this was one of the best.

review_preview: I really debated what overall rating to give as I had mixed feelings over El Club Allard. I have been to a few Michelin 1* restaurants before, this was my first 2* experience so my expectations were high, especially given the #1 rating on TA....
review_full: I really debated what overall rating to give as I had mixed feelings over El Club Allard. I have been to a few Michelin 1* restaurants before, this was my first 2* experience so my expectations were high, especially given the #1 rating on TA.  The presentation of each dish (we had the Rendezvous menu) was stunning, edible works of art - in particular the "fishbowl" dessert. But the intensity of taste that I was hoping for to match the beautiful presentation wasn't there in every dish. For example, the edible menu card looked great and was a novelty, but it didn't actually taste of much (hence the need for the dipping sauce). I feel bad saying that I was disappointed, as the dining room was beautiful and the serving staff friendly, professional and efficient.  Thanks to other TA reviews, I knew that there was no sign outside the restaurant. Look for the building number (looks like a private apartment building), and once you go into the lobby, you'll see a plaque for the restaurant. We arrived for the first sitting just as the doors opened, and there was someone to direct us from the lobby area. Please rate if you found this review useful :)

review_preview: We read the reviews and booked a table a few weeks before our trip to Madrid, but still weren't prepared for the experience at El Club Allard.  Just finding the place is a bit of an experience.  We arrived a bit early and walked around...
review_full: We read the reviews and booked a table a few weeks before our trip to Madrid, but still weren't prepared for the experience at El Club Allard. Just finding the place is a bit of an experience. We arrived a bit early and walked around the block looking for a sign, but couldn't find one. Eventually, we ran into another couple who were also looking for the restaurant and were greeted by a host. The meal itself was one surprise after another. From the menu itself, through the appetizers, entrees and desserts, everything was presented as a work of art. Every dish was interesting and some were just incredible. The servers were the most expert servers we'd ever encountered at a restaurant. They were excellent at explaining the dishes and made the service seem effortless - definitely enhancing the overall experience. While this was probably one of the more expensive restaurants we've had the good fortune to dine at, it was probably also the most memorable. If you go, you're in store for quite a treat!

review_full: We went here after having read the great comments on Tripadvisor and we were absolutely happy about this decision! The food is excellent and it is easy to order since there is an English menue.  We ordered the squird, the king prawns, the musaka, the potatoes and the salmon - and everything was perfect! As a starter, you get a bowl of olives and warm bread for free, such as a Bailey's shot before leaving. As a dessert, we had Chris' homemade chocolate cheesecake and as chocolate lovers, we both agree that it was amazing! One definitely has to try the Sangria, it tastes fruity and sweet! We would come back any time - we loved it!

review_preview: This restaurant has excellent food and the service is fast, friendly, and efficient. It is always busy but they find a way to get you in. The food is “fine dining” but the seating is “ diner style” small tables. I recommend this Taberna for...
review_full: This restaurant has excellent food and the service is fast, friendly, and efficient. It is always busy but they find a way to get you in. The food is “fine dining” but the seating is “ diner style” small tables. I recommend this Taberna for lunch or late night quick meal. Taberna el Sur is not closed like many restaurants from 2:00 to 5:00pm. The menu is chock full of Spanish favorites as well as few Greek favorites. Moussaka is a winner. A Friday lunch time crowd favorite is the paella topped with a large delicious langostino. Our favorites here are sautéed baby squid and grilled octopus. No worries. If you like chicken, fish, pork, etc.....They have it with a delicious local twist. The price of your meal relative to the value received is eye popping low. P.S. while the entire staff is friendly and helpful, John has been our server each visit and he is delightful.

review_full: Stayed near Atocha and discovered this taverna within walking distance from our hotel. review_preview: We loved the food and loved the service. Our spanish is less than good, but the servers were pleasant, helpful and patient. Got there around 9 last night. It was quiet, but was about to get by busy. We ordered the nachos, vegetable carpaccio, tortilla...
review_full: We loved the food and loved the service. Our spanish is less than good, but the servers were pleasant, helpful and patient. Got there around 9 last night. It was quiet, but was about to get by busy. We ordered the nachos, vegetable carpaccio, tortilla with onion and potato, pork loin, smoked cheese, burger, and everything was just so good. We also had a dessert that was a volcano filled with dulce de leche. I didn't try it, but everyone else liked it. We also had the tap beer, which was good and some of our party had a white after dinner drink, that they enjoyed. The place was hopping on a Tuesday night and we are thinking about going back again. Highly recommended.

title_review: Best tortilla de patatas in the world
review_preview: My partner and I started our La Latina tapas tour here and were not disappointed. The tortilla de patata is renowned with its caramelised onions (€4 a piece) and the duck ham on toast is also worth a shot. Larger portions were more expensive however....
review_full: My partner and I started our La Latina tapas tour here and were not disappointed. The tortilla de patata is renowned with its caramelised onions (€4 a piece) and the duck ham on toast is also worth a shot. Larger portions were more expensive however. Washed down with a copa of Rioja each the bill came to €18. Great atmosphere, try to get a table in the front room to soak up the ambience
